text: Such an amazing place!! I love that they have so many courses for beginners and advanced climbers! I'm a huge bouldering fan so their options make me.super happy! I have yet to start climbing with belay but they offer classes every top of the hour. Next time I go in I will definitely be doing that! Such a fun place to come with friends! I also bought my first pair of climbing shoes at their garage sale!! I'm so excited!! Thanks Hanger 18! I've always loved the climbing community and you've elevated that with your help and amazing gym! (Also can't wait to try out Monday night yoga!‍‍

I came here about 16 months ago with my bf about two and half years ago with my uncle, had a blast and decided to bring my g-friends.  None of them had indoor rock climbed before so we were so excited!There was literally only one auto belay for true beginners.  The other ones require more practice which we couldn't do because the beginner one was occupied most of the time.When I went two years ago, they taught us to buddy belay and I loved it.  I felt secured and stable compared to the auto ones.  (The rope is very tight and I can hang without it dropping me)This time around they wouldn't let us unless we passed the "test".  I couldn't remember how to rope in the climber (tracing the 8) and FAILED.  All they had to do with tell me like before and I would've spent two hours of fun, but instead I did one auto belay, got terrified of the instability coming down that I just couldn't get the nerve to go up again.I asked a random neighbor if he could buddy belay with me (he seemed like member) and I came down like a pro. Because he showed me how to secure the rope onto my harness, I asked them to test me again and they said I couldn't because I failed the first time.  I really wanted the girls to experience the buddy belay because they were having a hard time with the auto belay also.I have done this TWICE before.  Each times two hours each, I just couldn't remember the "8" tie in of the climber and if they could gone over with me it would have not been a problem.  And fine, let's say for liabilty reasons they aren't allowed to teach you anymore, but if I got taught by someone else and I knew the material later, why am I not allowed to get tested again? I only needed a recap.  This wasn't new material for me to master. I swear, Hangar 18's new management and their rules are so full of crap.  It is definitely not recommended for beginners.  Back in the day the whole right wall was filled with colorful grips to practice for beginners but now more than half of the rocks were missing.If they are doing so well with advance climbers, they shouldn't advertise this place for beginners.  O and the stingy business won't even let you dip your hand into chalk.  If this was an all included package for beginners, shouldn't that be included as well?I can guarantee you that if we could have done the buddy system, the girls would have had more fun.  I can say this because I am terrified of heights but I could climb to the top with the buddy system.  Literally out of four of us, only one could do the auto belay.  And one can climb so many times on the short walls that doesn't require the harness... I definitely wouldn't recommend this place for indoor rock climbing.  And although I only came like once a year, never would I step foot into this place.  Management is rude, bathrooms are dirty, not friendly for beginners, and it smells.  What a waste of money and a beautiful Saturday

They have more climbing walls when compared to the LB location, but the customer service here is seriously lacking. From the moment we walked in the guy at the front desk was really rude and just put a bad taste in my mouth. Honestly I don't expect much, but compared to the super nice and helpful people in LB this place sucked. If you are trying to learn I suggest you go to LB first. Because the bouldering is in the middle, a lot of people stand around the perimeter and watch so it makes it hard to belay in some areas. There is a big parking lot available. Shoes and a harness are $3 to rent. Canceled my membership.

Went for a kids birthday party. The sign in process is grueling. They want your life history. The children were guided by patient staff as they climbed up and down up and down up and down. They utilized maybe 3 different ropes for two hours. There was an upstairs seating area for the waiting adults. The party host was able to bring in food from the outside for the guests. It was fun watching the regulars climb and have fun. This was an awesome experience. The facility is very small.

I went to have drinks last night with my boyfriend and was surprised at the staff and cook. Javier 2 was so great and what a fantastic cook. We had the Phili cheesesteak and it was fabulous. We had a great time and enjoyed some great company. I would highly recommend the food and atmosphere. The music rocked as well. Thank You Javier2 for your conversation and entertaining us with your talent. We will be back soon .

Well, you can't beat the price compared to other bouldering slots, but you get what you pay for. They had about as many beginning paths as other places, don't know how the advanced people feel, but my problems with (1) the space is tight so there's not really a place to sit and watch as your take turns with your friends, people are all around you as it fills up, especially with a younger crowd and (2) the rocks were a lot harder on the skin than other places. Two of my friends ripped the skin on their hands and mine tingled (I refused to get to that point). It's perfectly fine for the price, but I'd rather pay more for protecting my hands and having more room and less teens.

So fun! I think this was my second time rock climbing in my life (does ymca rock climbing in middle school count as one? Haha) so I didn't know what to expect. Parking- lots of spaces available, esp if you come on the weekend Location- it's in the back of an industrial plaza. If you're coming from the 405, it's 1-2 plazas after the el Pollo Loco/shopping plaza. I came here with a group of 9 people (we had reservations) and we were all very new to rock climbing. They had two instructors for our group (Kevin and I think her name was kelly... I didn't catch her name bc I went to my car to put my stuff away. I feel bad bc she remembered everyone's name in our group) and they were so nice and supportive! They made rock climbing a lot less scary and helped us on our way up. They also kinda pushed us to try new walls and stuff which was fun. We all got rocked the next day bc we don't do any physical activity haha. We came on a Saturday afternoon and idk if it was considered busy or not. But there were a lot of people that had their own gear and whatnot. I think we were the only group that was new to rock climbing. Everyone else here was clearly experienced haha. Just be careful where you walk bc there can be people jumping from the top and stuff (one of their rules is to always look up). There was also a small group of kids having a birthday party. There's bathrooms in the back which also has a shower in it which is convenient for those who want to take a shower right away after. There is chalk everywhere so expect to get some on your clothes. LADIES, I recommend wearing yoga pants or something bc everyone will end up seeing your undies if you wear reg running shorts as you climb haha. It also smells like sweat once you walk in but you get used to it.

Very surprised by this location, my home gym is the lb one and this one is so much better. Really nice route setting on the auto belays and a nice diversity of climbing. I really enjoyed my session here! Will drop in whenever I'm in the hood.

"You get what you pay for"$36/18 Monthly/Daypass vs $125/25 Monthly/Daypass Hanger 18 vs higher quality bouldering gyms (such as Touchstone gyms) Its like 24 hour fitness vs Equinox. The price of Equinox basically weaves out the majority of the people. Soooo.... for $36/month and TWO for 1 Tuesdays = $18/month for you and a friend - get ready to get cozy with other members. If you have a little bit of patience and don't mind that the puzzles aren't changed often, Hangar 18 isn't so shabby. The gym is busiest during the weekday from 5-8PM and the weekend is generally the BEST time to go as you pretty much have the gym to yourself (with the exception of when theres a child's birthday party, then its a zoo).The attendants aren't the most useful and the restrooms can sometimes not be the best well maintained (There is hardly ever hand towel in the dispenser). But again, "You get what you pay for"

Decent place to get your climbing fix! You get what you pay for. For $5 the first month then $36 the following months, Hangar is a "chill" spot.You definitely meet a TON of folks here -- regular climbers, old & new climbers -- and everyone is friendly. The front desk has rad folks, with different personalities and humor.Personally, I've been spoiled by another rock climbing gym, and prefer the routes there. Hangar has some great routes, some not (they can get confusing when colors coincide for different ratings). The routes are a hit or a miss. Most people boulder here, but I also prefer top rope and lead climbing. So in that sense, Hangar may fall slightly short for me.Apart from that, it's a fantastic community and I love spending time with friends here. Climb on!

This was by far the worst experience we had. I purchased a Groupon for an all day pass with belaying lesson but when we arrived the staff was unfriendly and unprofessional. They did not explain anything to us on how to properly climb, it was almost as if we were expected to know how to use the facility. Even after I told them it was our first time there. The staff was eating and having cake and not helpful. Then we began to use the equipment and someone walked up to us to tell us that we were not properly using the climbing gear and when I told him that no one had bothered to help us or tell us how to use the climbing equipment, his response was "sorry we are busy right now" I was shocked and extremely upset by then that I decided to just leave. Never again! Staff is ridiculously unfriendly!

I'm not a bouldering expert so I can't say much about the routes. It was my first experience at this Hangar as my home gym is in Arcadia and I wanted to check this place out. I came during busy hours so take that into consideration when reading this review. The place is small that's a given I get that gyms get busy but what worries me is that kids were running around everywhere and it made me nervous that I might land on one. I was watching someone send a route and one of the holds slipped once she put all her weight on it causing her to fall. We laughed it off (but in the back of my mind I was like sh** girl did your life flash before your eyes?!) and she asked staff if she could get a wrench. The staff was super nonchalant and didn't seem to be surprised, which bothered me. Again I'm new to climbing and idk if this is a normal experience at a gym but I didn't enjoy my experience due to safety. Call me a negative Nancy but I'll look to other gyms and rethink my membership.

Came here as a guest with a friend who is a member. He gets one guest-pass per month, which is a pretty cool benefit.We came around 530pm during the week so it wasn't really busy. Some people on the walls and some on the boulders. Upon arrival I had to fill out a few forms on the iPads that are available. While it does save trees, they should probably restart those iPads since some were unresponsive or just super slow. I got a free pair of climbing shoes and they also have harnasses for hire if you want to scale the walls. My buddy explained the different level tags and colors to me and we just stuck to boulders. I had a good time for a quick visit but would probably not come here on my own because it does get really crowded at peek times and there is no AC in the hanger, just open gates. So it gets pretty hot in there. Also, the place smells worse than my boxing gym (which is saying something). Although I did hear that the monthly subscription rate is pretty low, which makes it tempting.

WOW this place ROCKS!! Ha ha haDISCLAIMER: I'm not a regular climber or anything. It was just something I'd been wanting to try. One morning, I woke up and decided: WHAT THE HECK today I will go climb rocks. And that's just what I did. As a little kid, I was TERRIFIED of rock climbing walls. You couldn't pay me enough to get on one. But I really wanted to try something new, so I decided to check out Hangar 18!!I got a Groupon for an intro lesson and a day pass. Rental gear was included (shoes and harness). I walked in and told the guy at the front desk that it was my first time. He had me fill out a waiver and look through a checklist. After that, he gave me a pair of climbing shoes and a harness and started the lesson. The guy who was helping me kinda seemed half preoccupied and kept leaving to take a call...maybe it was super important idk. But he was kind and patient when I kept falling LOLI went alone, so I wasn't able to take the belay class, but I did get to try autobelay climbing (climbing with a device that controls your fall/helps you with your descent, as opposed to doing this using another person) and some bouldering (climbing with no harness, shorter routes)! They have quite a few routes, so whether you're a total beginner or you have experience climbing, they're sure to have something for you! They have four autobelaysI have absolutely zero experience climbing. Like none. And I possess no upper body strength...so it was pretty challenging!! But this seems like a really amazing workout and a great community!! If you're in the area and don't want to go to laser tag or Gable House or walk around Del Amo or eat anymore (because that's what we do 99% of the time when we hang out in the South Bay), definitely check this place out!! I'd really like to come back with a friend to take the belay classBottom line: It's located towards the back of an area with a bunch of warehouse buildings. There's plenty of parking!! If you decide that this is up your alley, you can upgrade your lesson/day pass to a membership! They had a promo going on which gave you your first month for an additional $5--pretty rad!! You also get a guest pass if you do this. I almost signed up for the membership, but I'm not going to be in the South Bay for the rest of the month, so I decided against it...but I really did enjoy my climbing experience!! Rocks ain't so scary anymore. Also this place kinda really smells. If you try hard enough, you an ignore it, but there's no doubt that the stench is there...

Been going here for a little over a year now and have checked out many of the other gyms in the area to compare it to.Pros:-Many locations. This one is by my house and another one by my work place. Super convenient.-Cheapest price in the area ($36/month). This is really the only reason why I go here. You get what you pay for though.- No issues with parking.Cons:-Maybe the recent rain has something to do with it, but 1/3 of the gym is constantly taped off for no climbing. I guess they can't work outside so they just tape off a huge climbing area and work there. They have also been constantly changing routes. This might sound good, but having so much of the gym constantly not being open to climbing is getting annoying.-This place is absolutely filthy. The restroom is a mess.- Restroom is often out of supplies. Do they even bother replacing the paper towels?- 2 toilets in the men's restroom. At least one has been out of service for months now. I've lost track of how many consecutive months it's been.-Gym/workout area is a joke.-A lot of kids' birthday parties. Not a con on its own, but there can be a lot of unsupervised kids walking under you as you climb.-Poor lighting.-They seem understaffed. This doesn't affect me, but I've seen a lot of new people coming in and having to wait forever.

Beginner rock climber here!I'd been searching for a form of exercise that was different than the gym, running or yoga. I wanted to do something different to motivate myself to work out and care about my body. I bought the groupon on a whim and decided to come in today.The ages of the climbers ranged from little kids and beyond.That was when i decided to stop being a wimp because for real, those kids were going for it.The staff was so friendly, walked me around, showed me the different walls, levels, bouldering, clipping in, etc. I asked about how to get better, how to practice and more. He was encouraging and helpful and told me to start out with a couple times a week and that I would notice a difference if I just kept at it.These guys were great!

Went in on a Tuesday morning and there weren't that many people there which was good. We heard about the deal that they were doing with the BOGO free admission but since the desk lady wasn't there we got in for free!!!! With free rental shoes too!!! That was awesome. I've been to a lot of great rock climbing gyms and I have to say this one wasn't as impressive. There is definitely a tight knit community since it's a small gym, but there weren't that many walls to climb and I got bored after a couple hours. Other than that, it was a great experience since it was free!

Pros:- Close to work- Multiple so-cal locations- Easy and free parking- Relatively cheap monthly rateCons:- Poor lighting- No air conditioning and very little airflow- Staff seemed bored and disinterested - CrowdedOh, and finally, a hold literally almost came off the wall while I was climbing.I joined a different climbing gym the next day.At the end of the day, you get what you pay for.

A great way to exercise and hang out with friends at the same time. I just got a membership this month but I plan to continue it before I go to college. They have walls for all levels of climbers. Beginners are totally welcome; I know I definitely had little knowledge of the sport going in. It's a fun place with lots of laid back, friendly people.
Great little gym, learned how to climb here. Staff is laid back and helpful when you need them.

I finally bit the bullet and decided to cancel my membership. Even with the reasonable price tag, I couldn't justify paying for another month where the V3 and under routes feel sloppily put together (a hold actually ROTATED while I was climbing, yikes!), there's NO air conditioning, poor lighting, and the staff feel unwelcoming. In a pinch, this place has worked just fine but now that I've found another gym in the area, it's time to say goodbye.

I love Hangar 18 and have been climbing here for about a year or so. The staff regularly update and change the routes at Hangar. Route staff are very good at what they do. The routes are always challenging and fun to work on. The routes are usually maintained for long enough to give you sufficient time to master them. The climbing culture at Hangar is great. They even offer some classes to help you get into outdoor and lead climbing. Location: Hangar is located on the southern side of Rosecrans, just east of the Home Depot, Michael's and Ross Dress for Less shopping complex. Hangar is a little difficult to find as you cannot see it from Rosecrans. Keep your eyes peeled for the small sign you can see from the road. Hangar is towards the rear of a warehouse complex - the buildings have a light blue trim.  Proceed through the complex and make a left to the end and you will see the Hangar 18 sign on the building. When to Go: It is better to avoid Hangar 18 on the weekends. It is overrun by children and people that have never climbed before/infrequent climbers. Thus, it can be quite dangerous to climb around these people who don't know or follow proper climbing etiquette. Bathrooms/Changing Rooms: There are two ladies stalls and one handicap shower. There are 4 lockers in the ladies room- bring your own lock. There are also 5 or so cubbies to place your belongings in the changing room. While small, the bathroom/changing room does the trick just fine. Of course there is also a men's room.Weights: There are free weights at Hangar in the back corner by the ladies room. While this free weight corner does not match that of Equinox, it certainly is sufficient and offers a great bang for your buck for a climbing gym. Membership: Hangar 18 offers a very competitive rate for monthly membership. I recommend the monthly membership if you plan on climbing more than twice per month. Absolutely worth it.

Came here last week for the first time with 3 of my friends (all of us were new to climbing). We ended up getting the intro package which I think every person new to climbing should do. I don't know if we would have had a good time if we didn't get the intro package. Denise was the one who helped us. She was super knowledgeable, kind, and patient. She went through everything we needed to know step by step and made sure we knew what we were doing before she went on. After about an hour of learning the basics, we felt confident on our own and we have Denise to thank for that!The rentals here are $3 for shoes and $3 for harness. If you end up signing up for even a month, you might as well purchase some on your own.I ended up signing up for a membership after my intro class and I've been coming almost everyday since then. It's been a really fun way to get some exercise.There's a lot of reviews that mention the smell and I can't say that they're wrong. This place does smell like sweat when you walk in but you do get used to it (if that makes it any better). This place gets pretty busy around 6 and later. Showers available in the bathroom and water/gatorade available for purchase at the front desk.Overall, my experience here has been pleasant so far.

I really enjoy Hangar 18! They have a nice boulder/free climbing area, I personally enjoy that part the most. Hangar also offers yoga, work out classes and have a little work out area with weights which is nice when you want to mix things up.

This location like all the hangars are located in between some warehouses that can be a bit tricky to find. Coming from the 405 S freeway going N bound it'll be to your right side. However you can hardly see the Hangar 18 on this list of different companies when you enter in. It is pretty hidden and it'll be to your left side once you turn in right to the area. There's plenty of parking so that's a plus. It's pretty obvious you're by a climbing in the evening when you see a ton of cars parked and only one building that seems to be open. In comparison to Hangar LB, this one is much better IMO. There's a large variety of routes and problems and the sets are done a lot better here in this location. But again, this is just in my perspective.However one huge downside is how tight this entire gym was designed. It was not thoroughly thought through because bouldering and top roping are SUPER tight and close together. It's very easy for someone who is being lowered or coming down from the auto belay to accidentally kick someone who is standing by the bouldering walls. When it's crowded it can get really squished and tight and makes it difficult to want to climb because everyone is such close quarters. Some sides are a bit better than others. The sport climbing cave is pretty open and so is the overhung area for bouldering. Their grades for sport climbing are a bit different. Sometimes it's seemingly soft but there's one or two moves sometimes that are tricky and many times they could add an extra foot chip or a hand hold for shorter people.

Context: I don't exercise, I'm not very strong, and people can easily make more progress in one month than I can in a year. I was at Hangar 18 for about a year before I moved out of town. I've climbed at Sender One and Cliffs of Id, but this will always be my 'home' gym. I mostly boulder, but top rope or autobelay (there are about 4 of them) when I get tired. Space: This is an old school climbing gym -- the walls look like rocks, and the routes are set really densely together. That means that there are plenty of routes to climb, despite the relatively smaller size of the gym. I just moved to Austin and the newer climbing gym here jus doesn't have enough routes of each ability level. The routes: I've always had plenty to enjoy and to work on -- it never gets boring -- and then by the time I've gotten most of the ones that I am capable of, they change the routes up. Grading seems to be harder than at Cliffs of Id. The routes don't go up nearly as high as Cliffs or Sender One, but to make up for that, the routes are slightly trickier/more technique-y, and IMO, more fun. The only thing that I don't get here that I get at the other climbing gyms are the high top ropes -- there is a certain endurance that doesn't get tried here at Hangar as much. As for the variety of boulder types, they just started putting in volumes and introducing some more balance-y ones (in addition to the slab ones, the overhang-y ones, the dynos and the cave-y ones that they had already). So, as of recently, the boulder problems have become much more varied. The people: This is probably the best thing about the gym. This is BY FAR the friendliest gym I've ever encountered (I've now tried out 5 different gyms -- 3 in LA and 2 in Austin). Some people complain about it being crowded (especially after work on Mondays thru Thursdays). But this is precisely when I come and why I come. I never find that I really have to wait long to climb the route I want to climb (cos hey, we all need breaks), and the dense nature of the routes means that there are always people better and worse than you working on something in that same patch of wall. Everyone is SUPER supportive, cheering each other on regardless of ability level. There's always someone working on the same problem as me, and always someone better willing to give me tips to make me a better climber. Cost: $36/month, but see if you can catch their 3 months for $79 deal -- it happens several times a year, usually around holidays. SO worth it, especially compared to the price of other gyms ($60-$80+/mo). Parking: Easy. Large space. The other locations: One thing that is nice is that there are several Hangar 18 locations and membership in one gets you into all the others. Tip: There's a Monday/Wednesday crowd and a Tuesday/Thursday crowd. There's barely any overlap between the two sets of people. Pick a pair of days, start coming regularly, make lots of friends, and get fit.Ps - I love sender one and cliffs of id; they are objectively awesome, with much nicer facilities. That is without a doubt. Just, much more expensive too.

I should have posted this a few Weeks ago.  I visited this climbing gym in Hawthorne California in late June, But I wanted to put some time between my experience at this Rock Climbing Gym before I posted.  To insure it was not an emotional response.I have been to indoor climbing gyms around the United States and I am an avid outdoor rock climber.First the Pros:*Its close to where I work*it is indeed an indoor climbing GymThe Cons: (I'll just stop at the top 7)*The management is (that I dealt with at least seemed to be young and more a part of the gyms crowd, than professionals prepared to teach me anything about safety. I value my safety and the safety of other over everything else.  *The Gym was Dirty.  I don't mean your typical climbing gym dirty, I mean crud under your fingernails dirty.  From the Floor, Climbing Walls, Bathrooms and an odd little area with some dirty weights in a corner* The *Old dirty weights in the corner of the Gym but NOT in my opinion far enough from the Falling Mats.  It just seems a recipe for disaster.  *Why are these weights even here? perhaps its me but I have Never been to a climbing gym where there is a work out area inside the climbing area.*I did my best to be the guy who knows nothing about climbing.  I used their shoes though I have my own, used their harness though I have my Own, Etc, and asked question I knew the answers to.  I did this to see if I felt safe sending friends here.  I absolutist 100% do not.*in my personal opinion my 12 year old daughter could have done a better job teaching people new to the sport. she Climbs 5.12s, but is Very humble and wants to make sure everyone around her is safe.*If you are planning to use one of their auto belay Units (rather than Belay your partner) of which there are few, I would think again. They seem old and in need of service.*I feel Like I was getting in the Surf at my local Surfing spot.  Locals Only.  I would Never take my daughter here, Though she may teach them a thing or 2 Manners and how to climb.*Its only 2 stories (it may have have been a bit more but it deems even a bit less)*I don't feel safe to bring anyone new to the sport here.  2 Weeks later I tried out "Sender One"  I hate to plug another climbing gym here, but after my experience at this particular Hanger 18 in Hawthorne California, I had to. It was NIGHT & DAY difference!  Safety is their number one concern at all times. I will warn you upfront, it is more expensive.  But the First Rule in Safety is you can't put a Price on Safety!

I heard about this place from a friend that goes to the Long Beach location. My 5 year old loves to climber so I decided to take him as a treat. They lost a star for being unorganized and another one of for not being a real kid friendly place. My son was only able to go so high since the holds were placed at a distance that would require for you to be taller. My suggestion would be for them to create an area that is easier for the little ones to climb. After all they are the future of their business. With all that said, my son did have a great time climbing one area he figured out.I think next time I will try the Long Beach location for kicks.

Been here 2 weeks and been having a blast !Seen some bad reviews which kind of through me off But completely disagree The gym it's self is good size padding everywhere And NOOB friendlySaw someone complain that said gym was dirty It's not dirty it's just a GYM Chalk dust everywhere and people working hardAlso staff is great and welcoming not sure why someone would say they weren't If you want to be baby sat at a shinny just go down the street to EquinoxBeen 2 weeks and a total noob been a having a blast ever since

I purchased a one month membership from Groupon for 2 people for about $50 something which I think is a good deal. Hangar at this location seems kind of crowded and small. There is definitely a sweat smell since its packed and ventilation isn't that great. I think for how crowded it is, the space that each person needs to climb isn't big enough. They about 3 autobelay spots and a handful of belaying spots and a mostly bouldering walls. It's pretty obvious who's new and who are continuous members and some people can be quite jerks. My bf was climbing from doing the autobelaying wall and wanted to make sure the people below (who were in a circle chit chatting away.. just standing around) didn't get hit by him so I asked them to move a lil in case (they shouldn't be standing around there anyways having casual catch up session because it could be dangerous) he hits them and the eye they have me was like "eww you guys  are noobs and don't belong here". Like uhhh okay. And then while my bf was coming down he flinched because for newcomers it could be scary coming down the rope because I just let go of the wall and from up there you feel really high. Anyways, he hit the wall w his foot cuz he flinched and made a thumping sound and the guy next to him was like "Jesus!" (with this annoyed tone of voice). Anyways i apologized on behalf of my bf cuz I felt like he got scared.. But later regretted apologizing because he had a very asshole attitude about the small incident. Besides the members that go, I feel like everything else is fine. The staff was really nice & made us feel comfortable. If I decide not to go (it would most likely be because of the regular members). They seem to be nice towards each other and actually very friendly but they were not friendly to by bf & I. The vibe they gave us was no good. Not sure if it's cuz it was obvious that we were boobs or because we were Asian. Lol

I came to Hangar 18 to spend time with my cousin and left after I found that for a one day pass for first timers would cost $33 / person. I said verbatim, "I'm not chill with the pricing scheme", given that the monthly package is $36/month and I was only going to be in the neighborhood for a day not a whole month! I wish they could have told me this earlier before I filled out all the release forms. I might be back but only if the deal on Groupon is still available. FYI. This definitely not a Planet Granite (great ventilation and folks of all types) so keep your expectations moderately low.

I can't say my very first impression of this place wasn't that great. The moment I stepped in the door I got a good whiff of the scent of sweat, and really badly. I don't know if it's always like that or just that day but it was quite unpleasant. It could be cause there were just so many dudes inside that day. My friend that is a regular said he thinks a frat came for the day. Nonetheless, it was still fun learning to properly knot and pull the rope for your partner and climbing and trying to Boulder haha definitely need to work on my upper body strength. For newbies like me I think it's better to have your friend teach you everything and just borrow their equipment. For entrance and shoes rental I think it was all $20. Don't forget your water!

This place is terrible.  I waited for them to work on my car for over 2 hours then they came over and gave me an absurd estimate.  I thought they were working on my car but nope... just made me sit and wait for over 2 HOURS !!! Then gave me an estimate to do what should be an hours work.DON'T USE THIS PLACE.  Feels like rookies and a very some start up with little competence.

A few acquaintances have told me they prefer this location over the one in Signal Hill. Although I had never been to the one in Signal Hill and unable to compare, I do really like this location. There is a lot of space and plenty of walls for both climbing and bouldering (shorter routes/walls without the rope). I've never done bouldering prior to this visit. It's daunting at first, but so much fun! Staff is super cool. One of the employees had her beautiful German Shepherd free to roam around and look cute. There was a guy with a high ponytail working at the front, who nicknamed me Chandelier because he couldn't pronounce my name correctly. I appreciated that. They played classic rock all day (Lynard Skynard, Led Zepplin, Queen, etc.), which put out really chill vibes. I came with my friend who has a membership. I came as his guest. As a guest, entrance, shoes, and harness come free.

If you're someone with a pretty average to below average fitness level, this will most likely be a very challenging experience for you as it was for me! I enjoyed trying rockclimbing for the first time with my sister and her veteran rockclimbing friends. Although I don't know much about rock climbing I can tell this facility boasts a lot of popularity with their surrounding area and they seem to be well-stocked for all the materials that you would need. There are free climbing walls as well as the ones that use the harness. This place was completely packed on a Thursday night, and I found myself weaving between people for the majority of our visit there. It's definitely harder than it looks and I give a lot of credit to those ninja warriors out there. I believe it's $15 a day if you don't have a pass and somewhere like $50 for a month pass with discounts for various students and jobs. Cool place to check out if you're interested in trying out rock climbing or wanted it to become a more long-term fitness hobby.

3.5 ratingI came here with a group of about 5-7 of us. I had so much fun. This was my first time rock climbing and I was a little scared when I started. The staff was really nice on teaching you how to rock climb. We met some people there that go all the time and they were giving us tips on climbing. I had a lot of fun and would definitely come back!

This is my very first experience here. The staff is great, very friendly, and very willing to show you whatever you need to see/know.  The atmosphere is really cool and at the same time one can tell that everybody is working hard.  Cold drinks, locker rooms for men and women,  dumbbells, some free weights, and music are some of the amenities.  The groupon is great as well as it comes with a guest pass!  I'm a member as of today for at least a month so I'll see where it goes!
A basic climbing gym.  Nothing too fancy, well priced, and reasonably helpful employees.  Lighting was a bit dim, and bathrooms look a bit dirty/dated, but overall a fun experience for the family.

I'm a member of hanger since April 2015. I usually go to climbing after work (after 5pm) and of course, there's always many people climbing around that time. But it's not too bad. Try to avoid weekend or Fridays because there's a higher chance for someone to have a kids birthday party at the place. You can rent shoes, a harness and a blay. There's also autoblay to climb with. If you're a member, you get a free guest pass every month. It's always fun to climb with people.If you're a climber and want to buy climbing shoes, bring a list of shoes you want to buy. They will order the size you asked, one size down and up. And you can try them all three and decide which one you want to take. They will only charge for one you want. If you're a member, you get 10% discount and 20% additional discount if it's first time (not so sure about the additional discount).

My first official "gym" and I love it! Climbed a wall three times and as someone with 0 upper body strength I felt muscles work that probably never have lol!! Going to make this a new before/after work activity.

Purchased the living social deal which included a beginners lesson and all day pass. This is probably the third time I've been indoor rock climbing and we had an enjoyable time. There was one person doing lessons and he was overseeing another couple. He gave enough attention to both of us and made sure we understood and practiced the technique. Also the front desk person was knowledgeable and nice. I wish I had gotten both their names. We were comfortable enough to try out of the few walls. We would definitely come back!

I've been starting to boulder and it's absolutely fantastic. I can feel myself getting stronger and more fit. Note that I'm the worst at exercising, cardio, weight lifting and even stepping into a gym. Rock climbing makes getting healthy fun. You can go with friends, map out your course, use strategies to get better, and challenge yourself at your own pace. It's a great place to meet new people too. I've definitely bumped into old faces and met new people through rock climbing. My first few experiences have been nothing short of awesome. The man at the register was friendly and helpful. He gave me a full day pass for free once and even though my friend who has an annual membership already used her guest pass on someone else for the month, the man at the register let me use it too. The only things I think can improve about this place is:1) It can get crowded at peak hours (after 5 p.m. and weekends) as this place isn't that big.2) No water. There's a vending machine, but it'd be great if they had a water fountain of some sort. The first time, 3 of my friends and I went and none of us brought water. It was terrible. We were thirsty after just one climb.3) Utilize the seating area on top of one of the middle rock. I feel like it can be re-designed to make it more inviting/a good place to relax. No complaints. I think the pricing is reasonable, compared to many other rock climbing locations. I also like how there are multiple locations where you can go to if you have a pass.

I've been to about a dozen climbing gyms in my life and this one is the worst by far. Lots of time waiting for boulder problems or autobelays. Staff is almost a bit sassy. Whole place is a half finished warehouse. Cheaper than other options but not if they bill you an extra month! Went once. Got charged for a cheap first month and autopaid for a second. Despite that I've now paid for this current month, I'd rather pay $20 per day at the Stronghold than go back to this gym.
Hangar 18, it's the spot that keeps on giving. You like to climb?  They still got it. Now you've got some good burgers here during special events. What more could you want!
Great facility.  Staff is very patient with first time climbers.  Great instruction for all levels.

This place is bigger than the Long Beach gym and has a better variety of walls for top rope climbing as well as bouldering. Plus, more auto belays as well, which I'm a fan of. The few times I've been here have all been around noonish on Saturdays, which meant weekend crowds. While it can get pretty hectic when it's crowded, everyone has always been really chill, and I've never had a problem finding something to do. One of the great things about getting a monthly membership at Hangar 18 has been unlimited access to all of their gyms. I can't comment on what they're like for newcomers since I've always come here with my own gear and working knowledge of climbing and haven't needed lessons or whatever. As with the Long Beach location, it doesn't seem like they require a belay test, so be sure you know what you're doing before you start to climb. STEPH JUDGEMENT: Great facilities, can get really crowded at peak times.

Overall a fine gym after one session here. $18 for a day pass and a harness. Ratings seem fairly stiff compared to larger commercial gyms. Start and end to some problems are difficult to judge. In some places there are black, purple, and blue routes next to each other which is difficult to navigate.Main issue is that there aren't enough people working to handle signing people in, doing belay tests, and checking out gear. For a while there was one person working and about 30 people in the gym so we had to wait a while.Rating four stars because I expect slightly better for the price.

I've been climbing off and on since I was in high school but I never was able to do it consistently until now! It's a lot of fun for me and helps me get over my fear of heights too. Of course there's nothing better than the feeling of getting the to top of the wall and looking down to see how far up you are. It's scary but since I like climbing I get over it for the most part.This is my go to gym for multiple reasons:Affordability - Membership includes rental equipment and is $46 a monthVariety - The top rope and bouldering has a lot of options with different difficult levelsProximity - Last on my list but it's close to me so I come here a lot!This is the easiest rock gym I've been to where you can get a quick belay lesson and get climbing quickly. The people that work here are efficient and friendly enough, but don't expect to have in depth conversations. It's usually pretty busy and they have to keep helping customers as they file in. The belay device they use has it's own anti-locking mechanism which makes it less intimidating to belay here. It makes this gym more family friendly and crowded with more beginners and occasional climbers. There's a platform built up on top of the bouldering areas that they use for birthday parties. If there isn't one going on then it's pretty fun to go up there to rest and just check out the place. The other bouldering area in back you can climb onto also and walk around. Yep the gym is stinky and it's seriously a funk that you'll find at every rock gym. Everything always is covered in a fine layer of chalk because every climber uses it so much. I wouldn't mind if they cleaned up a bit more but I deal. At least here they keep the large garage style door open and fresh air wafts in. Usually it's warm inside but it can be pretty chilly on cold mornings with that huge door open.All in all I have a pretty good time here and get a good workout. It gets pretty crowded in here though and it can be pretty crazy. Since there's more families and beginners here you'll also see a lot of people climbing where they shouldn't be or not paying attention and walking under a climber. Just gotta be more careful coming here during busy times!

I'm entirely new to the rock climbing world and has only been to this rock climbing gym. However, in the time that I've been here, I have needed the newb course in belaying, and a refresher course after not going for a month+. Our first instructor was indifference and was just happy to be over with the lesson. Our second instructor though, Andre, was AWESOME! Although we were just piggybacking off of another lesson since it was meant to be a refresher for us, it became apparent for all of us that we really did forget everything. He was thorough and patience (despite the busy-ness at that time). After our lesson, my sister was belaying for me, and when it was time for me to rappel down, I didn't feel confident in her abilities since her hands didn't seem to be in the right positions. I stayed on the wall for a bit waiting for her to figure it out, when Andre came to the rescue! A+ for attentiveness! As for the facilities, I personally am satisfied. There are rock climbing with, I think, 3 or 4 auto-belay systems in place, bouldering, and a small area with weight machines (although these guys look dated and very sad). It does get crowded at times, but there are also times in which it's quite empty (my favorite time to be there).

If you're looking for an indoor climbing gym in Los Angeles, I cannot recommend Hanger 18 enough!  The staff is nice, the people that climb there are generally friendly, they change the routes often enough to keep climbers challenged and their prices are half of what anyone else is charging.The biggest reason I recommend them is because they stand behind their members - 100%.  Some friends and I had an issue where we weren't given what we'd initially singed up for... and we were rightfully disappointed.  However, once I shared my experience, Dave (Hanger 18's COO) reached out to me personally to right the situation.  It's great knowing you are doing business with a company who will stand behind their products and services!  Hanger 18 is where it's at!
So much fun, and the staff is great and really helpful! Definitely check out this place if you're looking for something new and challenging. Very reasonably priced as well.

Friend brought me in for free since members get a pass once a month. A day pass though is $16 though, so not bad at all. But seriously who REALLY climbs all day, they should have a by the hour/minute pass for me and my noodle arms x_X. They waiver sign-in process is quick and done from an iPad. Nifty use of technology to cut down on storage while saving some trees.  Great indoor climbing gym, I live near ARC but see tons of variety in routes here. The middle islands are golden for bouldering practice! Really fun way to mix up your work out, as you'll be using muscles you don't normally use. For example gripping tiny nubs with your fingers, will make you cry out pathetically as you attempt to open a Gatorade bottle at the end of your session!This gym does show concern for safety and covers it's assets well with paperwork. The entire floor is cushioned with additional soft mats you can drag around to break your fall, so I never really had a fear for my life moment at the times where I lost my grip and just had to bail. I didn't use the auto-belay tool but thought that was a nifty option. I have heard complaints from "real" climbers that all the mats and safety equipment just trains people to have poor habits, because in the real world there are no mats and to know your limitations.... yada yada. A gym is a gym, running on a treadmill isn't going to be like running on the real world, so as long as you have your expectations in check I think this is good starting place. Recommend you going with experienced buddies not only for safety, but to save time and they can show you the ropes... erm rocks... that are best suited for your level saving time. If you climb enough, I would invest in your own shoes as the ones here look like they have seen better days. Plenty of parking, but the site is easy to miss since it's not visible from the street. Note: Qdoba is nearby and makes a great place to refill all those calories burned. ;)

LOVED IT.Boyfriend and I were looking for some unique bonding time and this is exactly what we needed!Something fun, something we could take a lot of cool pictures, and something to coach each other on! The staff was all very very nice. They helped out a ton to make sure we were safe as possible while using the equipment to rock climb.It was also an intense workout. Lol. I didn't expect to sweat so much from rock climbing!!!Definitely coming back here!

Great gym, lots of bouldering routes with a good share of top rope. Having a ton of fun here, staff is cool too, they took their time teaching us how to belay. Can be very busy at times but everyones nice and respectful so it's not too big of a deal. The majority of the floor is padded so it puts you at ease to just go for it while bouldering. Top rope has a couple auto-belays too.

Great walls of L.A.! Love this place! It's a great place for beginners and advanced climbers, there are auto-belays and bouldering, and all sorts of goodness. Get ready for a solid workout and spending the day there!
Correction on pricing:Intro package: $30 for adults, $25 for kidsDay pass: $16 for adults, $11 for kids
This place is so amazing. My friends and I had so much fun after one session, we are definitely going to get year memberships. Jeremy was awesome, super funny, kind and patient. This place is a must.

This place seems to have a bad rap, but it's actually a good climbing gym. Large freestanding bouldering routes with caves and overhangs, and a variety of good too ripe and lead climb routes. Friendly staff (although sometimes the front desk sits vacant) and friendly climbers always willing to provide a little beta. Decent ventilation when it isn't a packed house, and cheap rentals. Get on that groupon to save money.

So you want to learn how to climb or boulder some rocks aye?Came here for the first time with the boy (who's a regular) for the first time as his guest.For a complete noob, hangar 18 was a nice, low key, good vibe, just climb on your own pace and no one would bother you kinda place. The space is not huge, but on a not too crowded night, beginners to season regulars all seem to find a place to climb.If you're new to this.. a few words of advice:-the place smells a bit funky. After learning about the climbing shoes you'll know why. You won't notice after a while-make sure you read the tags attached to certain rocks and follow the colors and codes accordingly. For beginners look for patterns marked with VB or V0. -If you get stuck, don't be afraid to fall (but fall with caution of course). The floors are super padded and have a bouncing quality to ease the fall. There are also extra pads to break your fall. -Watch out for climbers before you walk under a walkway etc, you don't want to break their fall.-Be courteous and don't climb a wall that someone else is on.-no gear? no worries, they'll have all the items for you. A note, the shoes are shared amongst all visitors. Although they spray it with disinfectants, if youre a big germaphob, you might want to invest in your own pair if you plan to come often.-expect to be sore the next day and don't expect to be as graceful and strong as the veterans, it's okay. They've been working on this for a while.-if your friends have chalk, as them for some. It'll make you nervous palms a little less sweaty and have a firmer grip. :) Overall a very nice experience. Can get a bit squished at times and hard to find routes for beginners, but definitely something fun to try out.

Im a newbie to Rock Climbing and this place is amazing.  Lots of colors on the wall and ropes hanging up high.  This place a shower if anyone is interested.  Nice people and are willing to help when in need.

Cheaper than Rockreaction, but lacking in so many ways.My friend and I bought a Groupon 2 for 1 monthly membership, and thought it'd be a good idea. I'm not an experienced climber, but I enjoy bouldering and have some minor experience. My friend... not so much.Upon entering, we realized that you really do get what you pay for.Poorly maintained, not well lit, kids running rampant, unamused/unfriendly staff, shoe rentals with holes galore, and a kind of claustrophobic feel to the place.The grading is poorly labeled, and it was difficult to attempt to properly follow a problem because most of the tape is on the ground and not on the wall. Being our first time here, it was incredibly frustrating.We'll be back, since we have a month pass, but I'm not looking forward to those labels, ugh.

This is the third Hangar 18 location I've been to, and quite possibly the worst one yet. I came to this location on a Friday night with a group of three people. The place seemed small and very crowded. There is a wide variety of bouldering routes, but there seems to be no organization. Many of the holds are slippery making it difficult to complete a simple V1 or V0 route. In addition, it seems as though the setters were very careless when setting some of these routes. I saw a lot of routes using red holds placed right next to routes using pink/red holds. It gets difficult to differentiate between where a route starts and where it ends. Also, the difficulty rating did not seem accurate. There were V1s that were easier than V0s and some V0s that had no sense of direction. The facility itself was somewhat clean. But it definitely needs more love and attention. They have a shower and bathrooms that double as changing rooms for the women (not sure if I can say the same for the men). They also have a small fitness area with questionable equipment. Overall I don't get the feeling that this is a safe environment, and I'm sure there are many other climbing/bouldering gyms in LA that are much better than this one.

Wow, how rude!!  My 6-year old nephew had to use the restroom, but they wouldn't let us in since we hadn't signed a waiver yet.  Just to use the friggin bathroom??  As a result, he peed in his pants...WTF!!!!  Not only did this place stink like hell, but because of this stupid waiver they just LOST 8 CUSTOMERS!!!

To start off, I've been to their Long Beach, Upland, Rancho, and Riverside locations many times and had wonderful experiences. Upon arrival there was a line of 5 people ahead of me, with one employee signing them up for their first visits. I knew it was going to take a while but luckily there was another employee at the counter. Or so I thought... they both fail to acknowledge their growing line of guests although four people queued up after me. The second employee was busy chatting up two climbers so I stepped up and asked if he could check me in. He proceeds to do so. They couldn't find my membership or my friends in their system so they had to call Upland to check us in. We put on our shoes and head to the back room where a group of 4 and all their belongings are sprawled out directly under the bouldering wall making it impossible for others to climb. We head to a second wall and there's two broken holds on the floor with extremely sharp edges. I bring it to the attention of the staff and a third employee just blows it off saying to just leave it on the counter. I inform him where it was, as he didn't ask, because there were a lot of kiddies climbing and I didn't want an accident to happen. Sure enough I head back and there a little girl about to climb it. I warn her and stand by until the guy shows up. We go on climbing but the vibe is just so off at this place. Nobody talks to eachother. Multiple climbers stand cross armed close by and stare you down in silence as you attempt problems. The holds themselves are old, dirty, slick and there are multiple same color problems side by side so they all blur together. The bathrooms were dirty and so was the floor, if the employees are in charge of the cleaning they need to take their jobs seriously. Talk about gross. To be fair, the layout was super cool and I was stoked to be there but the longer I stayed the worse the vibe got. My friend and I left after just 30 mins although we drove an hour to visit this location. While we put on our shoes a group of newbies were having a tough time with their harnesses and the employee said "it's way too big" from across the counter. She apologized that it was her first time and he just handed her a different one without explaining or smiling or showing any kindness. Seriously talk to your employees about having standards, friendliness, and actually doing the job they are paid for. Never visiting again and telling my friends.

Do you like standing shoulder-to-shoulder with several sweaty twenty-something guys? Do you enjoy the smell of feet and the languid gaze of indifferent employees? Then Hanger 18 is for you!I want to love this gym, especially for the price. But the truth is that it's PACKED on the weeknights and it's a pain in the ass to constantly check to make sure some idiot isn't wandering around underneath you while you're climbing.With that being said, the regulars here are super friendly. The routes are interesting (although not changed very frequently) and I was really into going for a few months. But after getting more into running and wanting to try some weight training, I think I'll be canceling my membership and switching to a regular gym.

My friend took me here on her guest pass and I was provided free rock climbing shoes and a harness.  The staff seemed chill, but definitely not enthusiastic when explaining climbing procedures.  You can tell in their voice that they've explained it many times.This place is smaller than I thought, but there were a good amount of walls to climb.  You can easily kill a lot of time climbing which my friends me did, spending a few hours here.  This was my first time rock climbing and I had a fun time trying all the challenging climbs.  We went on a Monday evening, and it was busy but not to the point where there were no walls avilable to climb.  You can definitely tell who are regulars and who are first timers, but everyone are minding their own climbs.  The regulars here seem to use this as their "gym" and they have a pull up bar and a bench press that people were using, but that makes me wonder if these people workout their legs.  It does tend to smell and that does depend how smelly the climbers are.  People can get extremely sweaty and the smell of feet can linger certain areas such as the bathroom.I don't know how I feel about getting a membership here unless you're really into climbing.  For me, this would get old fast but it was a great thing to try.

This place is amazing! I bought the Groupon, which included two introductory belay lessons. As my boyfriend and I waited for our lesson, we decided to Boulder (climb without a harness; don't worry, it's padded). For those of you that have never climbed, it's actually pretty scary/alarming. I fell multiple times and had to keep myself from crying. Elisabeth, the friendly and considerate receptionist (I don't know if that's the right word), saw my frustrations and took it upon herself to make me feel better. She said she wouldn't let me leave feeling so negatively about rock climbing. So I tried again and she helped me reach the top :)

Very crowded on thursday and friday nights, with far more people sitting around talking than climbing. Short walls, bouldering focused, few autobelays. Still it's the only place to climb indoors in the area and the monthly price is cheap. Everyone I've talked to has been pretty friendly. Some wall sections have bad lighting, I almost feel like bringing a headlamp to distinguish between route colors.You do have to constantly watch out people beneath you. I collided with an unsupervised little kid after a surprise fall who gleefully took the impact of a 150 lb man, and shocked a couple of women getting setup for top roping. Some signs just telling people to LOOK UP might go a long way.

When we first walked in I was taken back by the strong odor of sweat and feet. It reminded me of Bikram hot yoga in dtla... Of course much lighter and tolerable . About 30 mins into it I forgot all about the funk and I was enjoying myself climbing the easier yellow gums on the wall.Staff was friendly and there is huge parking area so that was a plus from a person living in an area where finding parking may be easier than finding gold. Only down fall is as a beginner I have to go with someone that can belay me or pay for an instructor. There are free climbing walls but the over all area is small and it gets packed (went on a Monday night). The prices are on there website.  There will be entrance fee, equipment rental fee, and shoe rental fee. I strongly advise you to check their website first. Overall I had so much fun I ended up joining the monthly club. Its really a great workout for my back and arms since beginners tend to pull up and not push up.

What a joke.My friend and I bought a Groupon for a trial membership and after running into a kiddie party at the Long Beach location backtracked to Hawthorne for a quieter experience.  I've been to the Long Beach Hangar 18 once many years ago and have never rock-climbed since.We walk into the Hawthorne location to the girl behind the counter preoccupied on her phone.  Tell her we're new and have never done this before and she shoos us over the the iPads to sign the waivers and whatnot. Strike one. After we're done, it takes a second to get her attention because, again, she's preoccupied on her phone. Strike two. She's talking fast through all the obstacles they offer like we understand what she's talking about, and tells us that we have the option of taking a lesson for the belay or bouldering. Did she forget that we're new?? Of course we want a lesson! Strike three.She tells us the lesson is 30-45 minutes and we decide to wait. After a self-tour of the facility my friend and I go back to the counter to ask who we'll be taking a lesson with. She tells us it would be with her or her co-worker (who is walking around barefoot, trekking back and forth from his lunch on the counter to the group he's giving a lesson to. Worst yet, he's approaching them with a mouth full of food!). Strike four. It took us all about two minutes after to decide that we didn't feel safe rock climbing at this facility, especially since we're NEW to this whole thing. If you just signed a waiver saying that you could get seriously injured or DIE wouldn't you want to work with staff who understood that and cared???From what I remember, the LB location was much more attentive and had a better understanding of the safety of their patrons so we'll be utilizing our membership there. Oh Hawthorne..

Man..... I hate to do this but this gym is UNSAFE. I have been climbing for 15+ years all over the world and never have I felt so unsafe as at hangar 18. The top ropes were not double wrapped at the top so if you are belaying someone heavier than you, if they fall, you will go FLYING. Not to mention that lowering someone off a top rope route means serious burning of your hands even with the required gri gri. I fell once and my partner was sent flying, and I slammed hard right onto my elbow from about 6 feet (normal top ropes shouldn't drop more than 3 feet or UNLESS you're lead climbing which is a whole different beast altogether). This is unacceptable and totally avoidable by double wrapping the top rope for a little more friction. Also, the staff is totally unprepared. The young lady that took care of us was really sweet but definitely sang Disney songs at the top of her lungs for the last 30 mins of our time there (was she trying to get discovered or remind everyone it was almost time to clear out? Her rendition of "let it go" got me outta there really fast I'll tell ya). Also, when we were "tested" for our belay aptitude a boy no older than 15 came to watch us belay each other. He told my husband he didn't need both the knots as a climber- only one (!!!)After we passed the "test" I asked if we needed a certification card and he laughed and said no we don't do that. When I just looked worried and shocked he laughed again and said "yeah.. we should, but we don't" and that was that. Meaning do NOT find a top rope partner here at hangar 18 because they will not know what they are doing!On one of the walls there was an open closet jutting out right into 3 of the top rope routes. I tied it closed using another top rope and when one of the staff walked by and we asked him to close it he shrugged and said sorry they lost the key. He left my rope the the way it was and walked away.There were shards of glass in the carpet near the cubby areas and the vending machines.This place is obviously abandoned by whomever owns it, and it is frequented by twenty somethings that either aren't serious about climbing, don't care or don't know any better. Do NOT bring your children here. The climbs do not vary much in difficulty or style even if they are labeled differently so don't expect much there. They are obviously all set up by the same inexperienced climber.Anyway, the gym is cheap, so I guess that's nice. The staff told us people buy groupons indefinitely and never pay the full $50 membership... And it's obvious given the state of the establishment.Climb at your own risk and after they make you sign 10+ pages of liability waivers lol

Me and my friends went to hangar 18 in Hawthorne yesterday. I have to admit that I did not like it at first because everything looks and was pretty close together, which made me feel uncomfortable. It turned out to be a great gym after spending almost 5 hours there :)The great part about this gym is, that it had padded floors around all climbing spots. We went to the one in long beach 2 week earlier and it only had mats you can pull towards the bouldering spots.Back to Hawthorne. I read previous reviews about the bad service but I can not agree with that! We did have to wait a few minutes but that is normal due to the day of the week ( sunday) we decided to go climbing. We purchased a groupon including a lesson and all rental gear which was a great deal! The instructor we had was very nice and explained everything very well! The great thing about the gym in Hawthorne is that there is a bouldering spot where you can "top off" and use a ladder to get down again. It was great to know that you don't have to jump off the top or boulder down. You can simply climb up and walk down!The bathrooms were not very nice though. Even though it had a shower for people who use it as a normal gym, the individual stalls could have been cleaner. The reason why I did not give out 5 stars is because of the bathrooms and that it was extremely crowded around  4pm which made it hard to move around and climb in different spots.Overall it was a great experience, the padded floor and the topping off was definitely worth going there for :)

I knew I forgot something...well my friend and I got a groupon to come here about 3 weeks ago and it was so fun. The space was nice, Elizabeth was sooo nice and there was a nice dog in the front. I was a little scared because heights arent really my thing but we had a blast. Im def coming back

Came here on my own to challenge myself. The staff was very friendly, helpful, and informative. They showed me the ropes -- literally -- and gave me guidance on how to use the auto belay system and utilize their color mapping to make the most of my climb. Great experience!

We came with a group for 5...  ( 4 adults and 1 child). We were all beginners. And our instructor was super informative. it took a few tries to properly tie a knot on the rope. If it was incorrect he definitely corrected it. he Double checked how we had the equipment on. As soon as he thought we were confident enough in what we were doing we were left alone. We all learned a lot, had fun and no one got hurt. In the beginning my daughter kind of freak out when she was instructed to push off the wall while hanging on the rope. Luckily, our awesome instructor came up to help her out. Plus he went up with sandals without a rope. He's a cool guy. Definitely, made her feel comfortable and within minutes she was confident going up and down. Awesome atmosphere. Will definitely come back. You should definitely come here.

Dope gym, little circulation.great sweat in 15 min. One top out boulder wall, 3 auto belays.crash pads and soft landing floor. Looking for a quick hour session for pure sweat hit it up. Bath room/Changing room.But I came to climb. Draw backs, I went in middle of day.

My friend and I bought a Groupon for the Belay Lesson, entry fee and rentals. We showed up in the middle of the day on Saturday and immediately got told that we would have to wait two hours to get a Belay Lesson because all the equiment was rented out and there were two groups ahead of us. It felt like they just wanted us to leave so they wouldn't have to deal with us, but we drove 30mins to get there and use the Groupon so we were staying. So whatever, we started bouldering since we were already there and if the lesson happened it happend. The routes are hard to find, a lot of the tape has been kicked off and some were just confusing to start or finish. It was super crowded with kids so we couldn't find many routes to work on. Not to mention worrying that a kid would run under you before you jumped down. Finally after an hour someone says we can have our belay lesson. The whole lesson the instructor was obviously bored. When he gave us a task that would take a minute he pulled out his phone. It made me not really want to climb. This place makes me not want to climb.

The good: it's cheap. The bad: basically everything relating to an enjoyable climbing experience. Holds are spray painted (awful!), shiny, and slippery. Route setting is lazy and uninteresting, relying on crimpy holds to add difficulty. Walls are short. Tape is beat up and it's sometimes hard to tell which holds are on your route. Only alpine bod harnesses (uncomfortable, not padded) available for rental. Definitely the worst of the local gyms (Rockreation, Sender One), and I don't think the cheaper price makes up for it. When Sender One opens up its LAX location, I don't see this location staying open for long.

The facility looks great and fun...if you are an adult or have an older child.  Unfortunately for our 5 year old, it was a bust.I called before going and they said kids as young as 1 could participate.  Great.  After we arrived, but before signing in/paying, we looked over the facility and he definitely wanted to do it.  Unfortunately, we wee not allowed to actually go in and touch the climbing walls.  Liability I guess but surely a staff person could have supervised as we walked the four feet to compare his size to the handholds.After 10 minutes of waiving all liability for everything under the sun, they fit him up and gave a brief demo on how the retractable safety line works. Then he tried, and tried, and tried but got no where.  Very frustrating for him and me.  So we left. $13 for a few minutes of anger and disappointment.I'd recommend a few things for this facility -It is clearly made for people of a certain height, be upfront about that.Some younger/shorter kids can probably find success, but with some guidance/help from the staff.  They didn't offer any, which is fine, but again they could be more upfront that the facility is not especially kid-friendly.Finally, if they are going to serve kids, they should get smaller harnesses.  While his fit tightly, the carabiner attached so high that it was jabbing into his chest/throat and hurt.  That was part of the problem. I'd say they should have refunded our money, but I didn't ask for it and, suppose, we did use the facility (for a few minutes). Bottom line, for older kids and adults, I bet it is a lot of fun.  For us, we won't return for a few years.

If a climbing gym and a crackhouse had a baby, it would be Hangar 18. I was down from SF and figured I'd check it out. Filthy, ancient holds ( some have actually been SPRAY-PAINTED ) that seem like they haven't been changed-out in years. It's great they keep the hold colors consistent through the problems but they are covered in so many layers of chalk and rubber you actually can't tell what color they are once you are up and climbing.      The bathroom reminds me some I've been in on Sunset. If they just added a condom machine and I'd swear I was at a strip club. Awful.     I don't know if MadRock owns this place but it's the only brand they sell or rent.     I guess the only thing that saves this place from one star is that there are some interesting problems, and they are graded properly. But, seriously, this place is so bad that it makes me want to open a real gym like Planet Granite or MetroRock and give Angelenos a place to climb.

Pros:- large gym with a good variety of bouldering/climbing routes- the employees are very friendly and ready to answer any of your questions- the routes are changed up every couple months to keep things fresh- they have a training area/small gym that you can use to strengthen the muscles you use for climbing- they have a lot of good beginner routes, great place to take someone who has never tried climbing before & might be a little nervous at firstCons:- kind of difficult to find the first time.  There is a small sign out on the street and it is way in the back corner.  I got way lost going here for the first time- Unbelievably crowded on weekday evenings.  At 7pm on a Tuesday it was packed to the point of waiting your turn to try most of the bouldering routes.  It's not too bad with the people who know what they are doing but some of the beginners will start climbing a bit too close for safetyIf you're a student it's only $28/month and that includes shoe & harness rental.  If you're not a student, check out groupon, they always have a lot of deals going on.  They have many locations throughout Southern California and if you get one of their memberships you can use it at any gym & you get one guest pass per month so you can bring a friend.

Pros: -4 auto-belays for people who want to do rope on their own-a good variety of top roping with rating from 5.8 and up-nice selection of bouldering, overhangs, caves etc-one structure of the bouldering allows you to top out -weights in the back, and place to practice your hand grip strengthCons: -pads for bouldering are thinner than expected, because they have padded floor. But be careful, I hurt my ankle when I fell off a bouldering problem, even with a pad below me. -rating system seems kinda off. I can climb 5.8-5.10c in this gym, but everywhere else, I'm around 5.8 and 5.9. Bouldering, I can do V0, V1, and V2 here, but the routes are harder at other gyms. If you're new at this, come here. There will be a lot of stuff you can do, so don't be discouraged. I got membership about a week ago and came 5 times already. You can get better fast if you work on technique and not strength. Climbing is a mental problem lol. If you love it enough, buy shoes, expect to spend around $100 on it. It's worth the money. Buy chalk, especially if you sweat. It's only $2 for a piece of chalk.

This was my first rockclimbing experience, and I can't wait to come back. We bought the climb for one month anytime package. They have all kinds of different colored rock climbing combinations, which makes great use of a smaller space to create many routes to climb. Our instructor, Franz was completely patient, and made us all feel safe throughout the entire experience. And that's saying a lot considering I am somewhat afraid of heights.  If you need a full body work out in a fun way, this is my recommendation for a group of friends or even going for on a date with someone.

Do not fall for their scam.  I purchases a Groupon for this location for 2 people. We wanted to try out rock climbing but found that it was just not for us.  The women we spoke to when we signed up assured us we could cancel over the phone as long as we canceled 2 days prior to the expiration of our month passes.  When I called to cancel my membership while I was out of town on business a guy picked up the phone and began telling me I was lying because they do not do that.  He told me I could not cancel my membership over the phone and that unless I can make it back by the 30th that I was shit out of luck because they were going to charge my card.   I came in on October 1st which was my first day back to get refunded due to them initially stating I could cancel my membership over the phone and the guy helping me said nothing he could or would do and if I really needed the 66$ that I could call and bitch to my bank which is exactly what I ended up having to do.  I asked for a manager and he said they are all managers which is absolute horse shit.  This business is just like any other gym.  I will not be back and I will not recommend it.  I have sent a letter to the Better Business Bureau.

I first came here a couple years ago when it was called Beach City Rocks. Although the name has changed, everything else looks the same. All members are allowed to bring one free guest a month and I was invited by a friend of mine. Shoes and harness were also included free of charge. Another friend and I took a quick belay lesson. The instructor wasn't very friendly and seemed very rushed while explaining how to belay. I didn't feel very confident demonstrating the belay techniques after his brief explanation but took my time and got through it.My friend and I actually ended up climbing the free walls (bouldering) and it was a lot of work. The best technique is to not just use your upper body strength, and I learned that the hard way. There are many different levels to challenge yourself. They also have a couple auto belay climbs if you don't have anyone to belay or if you don't trust anyone.Other than the odd staff this place is good but can get crowded. For now I'll probably just milk my friend's free guest pass until I can build up more upper body and core strength =P

God bless the staff. They are incredibly helpful and nice. I just went to a gym in San Francisco and it has shown me why I come to Hanger 18. The staff will help you. They care and they don't want you to fall to your death. One of the front desk chicks spent a ton of time showing my friend how to use his harness and how to belay. She was a great teacher. As for the actual gym. The routes are fun and challenging. The wall shapes and inclines vary. The walls may not be as tall as the other gyms but this is made up by the challenging placement and variation of holds. They change the routes up about every other week which keeps things interesting. There's a good bouldering section. The price is unbeatable. There's not many frills like fancy white towels and work out machines but I come here to climb walls. If I wanted workout equipment I would join a work out gym not a climbing gym. I'm super happy with this place.
Not worth the hassle. Not a safe environment. No manager or first aid certified person on site at all times

Gave this a try. Got a groupon a couple of friends along with my wife. We camein and were greated by a nice dude.
