It was 10 am so he was the only one there and was already giving a lesson.we waited a bit as he went back and back again helping us and the climbers in the lesson. Despite that he did a great job in not forgetting we were there. we got our lesson and just had a blast.time flew.so fast  we were there fron 10 to 230pm and by this time it was packed. This place was filled with great helpful people. We would definalty make this trip again. We live in burbank  wish it was closer but it is definatly worth the drive. Alert for firstimers soak your arms in a bath when u get home and pop some motrin befor u go to sleep... lol I guarantee that if u dont you will be hurting very much. :)

My brother who is a huge climber describes Hangar 18 as the dive-bar of rock gyms. The price is right, and people who are in the know find it meets their needs just fine. If you want to class it up, there's always Sender One (which he calls the Equinox of rock gyms). But for me - beginner climber - Hangar 18 does the job spectacularly. This location has friendly staff, plenty of free lot parking. It can get very busy, and kid-filled (they apparently host birthday parties here) on the weekends.

On your first visit here you will definitely get lost. Super hard to find off of Rosecrans and then it's all the way in the back of the lot in a warehouse-looking building. Just spot 10 extra minutes to turn around if you are meeting people.Luckily I was given a ride here with rock climbing pros who had been coming for years so they knew where to go and told me exactly what I needed to do (put my harness on, tie myself in, tie the figure 8 knot,  the rock climbing "jargon", use my legs more than my arms...ect)I have rock climbing shoes and used a harness of my friend's so I'm not sure about rentals. I would never come here without some prior knowledge of rock climbing first, or it would be a bit confusing.I used a punch on their card ($80 for 10 punches) but I will either get the student discount (unlimited month for $28) or a punch card of my own next time.Parking is ample and free.

So my friend asked me to go rockclimbing, I thought...It's just a rock. How hard can it be? ...(pause)Staff was helpful (all 1 of them for the whole gym, so service can be faster, but it was friendly)I tried crawling on the top of the inverted walls - I definitely don't have good rock climbing technique, but did a lot of pullups as a kid. And, my mom put me in Kumon so I know how to play puzzles and do arithmetic.  But when I'm hanging upside down, I'm thinking... I have no clue what to next.  It's like...I'm all brawn, no brains, baby.All this education, learning how to be well put-together. What for?  When really my sole aspiration is to be a cockroach and hang upside down from rocks.

Took a trip to Socal earlier this month with my friend, and considering our obsession with bouldering and our desire to become spidermonkies, clearly we scouted a groupon before anything else. Came here at 8pm on a Friday night and it wasn't too crowded and we only had about 2 hours to climb. Filling out the waiver didn't take too long but waiting to get everything set up with the guy at the front desk took a long time. He was slow and unfriendly (looked annoyed and pissed off), made me feel uneasy. This isn't really a place known for bouldering,Their routes don't seem to change often, which doesn't matter too much to me since I don't live in the area. HOWEVER, the holds are very poorly maintained (chalky, slippery, old) and made me feel privileged to climb at my regular gym. I would come back to try their top roping if I was in town but I wouldn't go out of my way for this place. GOOD STUDENT MONTHLY PASS PRICE!

I don't know much about climbing gyms, but I know I enjoy bouldering at this one. Maybe it's just the quality of the company, but either way I'm sold. There are plenty of routes to climb, and though I haven't tried the top roping, but those people look like they're enjoying themselves too. The best part about bouldering here is that there are really soft crash mats and the nicely padded floor is quite forgiving. Good thing or I think I'd be dead by now...

I'll start off by saying that the mission viejo gym has the best vibe out of all the H18's. I came here already as a member so I didn't really need any interaction with the staff but I can definitely see what everyone else is talking about (regarding piss customer service). I walked in and wasn't greeted by anyone... actually tbh I could have just walked on through but I scanned by card anyways. Not one person came by to see how anyone was doing. Whatever.There is a ton of routes to climb, problems to solve, however the heck you want to say it. That is the one really great thing about this location. There is so much more variety compared to my usual location that I'm actually quite a bit jealous! I'll definitely try to come back to this place once a month just for the variation.

I had a groupon so my bf and I decided to check this place out one afternoon.  We are both beginners, so we were looking for some easy walls to climb.  When we got there we got some really good instruction from one of the employees on climbing basics, belaying, safety, etc.  After about 30 minutes we were able to climb on our own.  I have been climbing only once before, and the gym I went to had higher walls than Hangar 18 which made for a more enjoyable climbing experience.  Also this gym did not have many beginner walls to climb.  Overall there wasn't a whole lot of space to climb either.Overall I think this was an OK climbing gym.  It would be nice if there was more climbing space inside, but overall I think I might go back.

Pros:- large gym with a good variety of bouldering walls - plenty of fun challenging routes for all levels (including beginners such as myself!)- they change the routes every few months to mix things up- plenty of mats if you need that extra bit of reassurance - $28/month for students!! Includes shoe and harness rental!! Best deal in the area! Cons:- Unbelievably crowded on weekday evenings. Best times to go are Friday nights and Sundays!! This place is hands down the best bang for your buck. Awesome gym! Check it out! Groupon always has great specials if you need further reason to go!

A little embarrassed to admit it, but my climbing experience has always included a nice gent setting up and checking the ropes for me.  While I have tons of girl friends who also love to climb, not a one of us felt comfortable setting up ropes for ourselves.  On my first visit to Hangar 18, Elizabeth caught my date setting up the ropes and insisted upon giving me a full training and watching me walk-through the process several times.  I am so grateful!  Knowing the ropes meant 1) my date didn't fall to his death, 2) I gained confidence, and 3) Hangar 18 got a new client.  Smart girl - thanks Elizabeth!!

I have been a fan of the Hangar 18 gym in Upland for a few years now and I was in the LA area so I thought I would check out the Hawthorne location. Before going, I purchased a Groupon deal to get belay lessons since my girlfriend has never been before. When we arrived, we were able to check in with the person at the front desk and get our equipment, but he told us to wait for the next available instructor.... that's when it all went downhill.We were told that we could check out the gym and do a little bouldering while we waited. As I was checking out the gym, I noticed that several of the floor pads were ripped and falling apart with pieces of foam scattered everywhere (strike one).My girlfriend and I continued to try a couple of bouldering routes, but we were only able to very few routes that were V-B and V-0, none of which she was able to complete. As we tried to give it a go, we quickly found that these routes were way too difficult for a beginner. In my opinion, their idea of a V-0 should really be a V-2. Their ratings on some of these routes were ridiculous. I was able to complete a V-4 route that  was easier than a V-2 that I found right next to it. Rating for their routes were way off! (Strike two)After about 30 minutes passed, I saw a couple (who had checked in after us) getting their belay lessons. I was quick to follow up with their staff and was told that someone was about to help us in just a moment... back to bouldering we went. About 20 more minutes went by and we saw a large group of kids come in for a birthday party and get checked in right away and were given their equipment and lessons. We were completely forgotten about because the staff was too busy to handle their customers. (Strike three)We packed up our belongings and told the staff that we were unhappy with the service and that we were leaving. The person working the front desk could have cared less about what we thought and gave the sarcastic response "Sorry!"Well, here I am to say "Sorry" to you for losing a customer... I will NEVER go to the Hawthorne Hangar 18 again. Good thing they didn't actually redeem my Groupon :) These guys should really learn from the Upland location! If you are looking to go to a good rock gym in the LA area, Rockreation in Santa Monica a great place to go.

THanks to groupon i got to check out this place. I really like it! however i did not like the smell..this places doesnt have that great of air circulation.other than that... i love rock climbing! it's so fun!!! and this place is great, there are different courses and the staffs are awesome - so friendly and cool to talk to. and if you have little kids.. have a bday party here! i saw a group of kids and they all had a blast climbing to the top!! i'd definitely come back and do more rock climbing! perhaps get so in shape that i can boulder (yeah right)

Let me start by saying that I learned how to rock climb at Sender One in Santa Ana. It's a great gym (see my review on that as well) but it is just such a far drive from Torrance and the rest of the South Bay. Came to Hangar 18 since it's about 20-25 minutes from my house. The price is also approximately half of what it costs at Sender. Price and proximity are the two positives; here is why I rated it with two stars:As other people have stated on Yelp, it smells like a stuffy, dank, and sweaty gym from one of the older locker rooms at Torrance High School. It's relatively dark inside and the walls are not very visually appealing. Now I know that may sound a bit stuck-up and un-pure to a climbing enthusiast that sees these walls as realistic but, what can I say, it's just not as inviting and energetic as some other gyms (including the Hangar 18s in the OC).Also as mentioned by other reviewers, the customer service is nothing to be proud of. Fortunately I didn't experience anyone that was rude. All the employees I've interacted with have been quite nice, it's just that the front desk often sits empty for long periods of time and there doesn't seem to be much urgency if you're waiting there.The routes and problems are all pretty tough. I'm all up for a challenge and I am pretty determined to improve at new hobbies but a V0 at other gyms feels like a V2 at Hangar 18. The routes are color-coded to an extent but some still use old pieces of colored tape to mark the holds of a given route. Oftentimes two problems that sit right next to each other will be very similar in color (like faded orange and orangish-red). It's a bit annoying. The problems also intertwine amongst each other quite a bit. Now, I could see someone arguing that this is more realistic to real bouldering and that problems are not laid out all pretty and easy in nature. That is valid but it doesn't matter much; I prefer the design/layout at Sender One. One Yelper very smartly referred to Sender One as the Equinox (a high-end fitness gym in Manhattan Beach) of climbing gyms. The way I see it, although it's double the price and three-times the distance, I spend 2-4 hours at the gym when I climb and so it is worth it to me.Lastly, the place generally feels cramped. Combine that with the fact that there aren't many V0s, V1s, or V2s and that means you're constantly climbing next to much more experienced climbers. This can feel a bit awkward for a beginner. At the end of the day I thought about keeping my membership and still go to Sender One only once a week or so but I decided to just stick with Sender.

Well I started going to the one in upland because my College is right next to it. This Hangar 18 has harder routes, perhaps because the walls are shorter. There are always a ton of people there and they even run out of gri Gris some times.But for the unbeatable price of 27/month for College students, it's worth it I guess. This fact also keeps a young crowd here and it's nice because I run into College friends from time to time.In the end, the community here is great and I will definitely stick with hangar 18, especially when I have a job :p

Not the greatest facility really, but the staff is great.  Their little training session for newbies is the best in this area and I've climbed at all of the gyms around.  They have the cheapest memberships and the other climbers are usually friendly.  You can join the meetups there to meet other people too.

I came here twice with a Groupon to learn how to do these things. I went twice because the first time I was scared and my arms were tired so I wanted to do it again so I could get to the top.The class is great, but it would help if they had a reservation system because we waited an hour. It was nice of them to let us boulder around until they were ready, though that is what made my arms tired to begin with. And it kind of changed the schedule of our afternoon. Also, I guess it can't be helped, but it would nice if they had better ventilation. Otherwise, I really liked the experience. The instructors are friendly and I would recommend it to my fellow beginners.

I came here for a slightly more exciting bonding hang with my little brother who was visiting from Georgia. The two of us haven't climbed anything together since getting stuck up in the oak trees by my grandmother's house when we were kids. I found the staff to be welcoming. Andre in particular was very thorough and patient with explaining all the safety rules and giving us the encouragement to make it to the top (in spite of our collective fear of heights.) I highly recommend this location for a play date.

Fun! Had a groupon for intro to climbing class and it was definitely worth it. They take safety seriously here, though it's obviously still a possibility of getting hurt. A friendly guy gave us the rundown, equipment, and an intro lesson. There were some periods of short waiting, but it seemed decently busy at the time. The instructions were thorough, but brief. We were the. Left on our own to have fun and climb around. The instructions were more about safety and procedures than about actual climbing. I think it may be helpful to have tried it a time or two before coming, though I'm sure they would be happy to go more in depth should you have questions or need extra help. A good place to climb on a rainy day.

We had one of those Groupons so we decided to go to the Hawthorne location since it was closer to where we were coming from.   I've been to the Upland location, which I think is much better in so many ways.  First off, the Hawthorne location was super small and really not high at all compared to the other one.  When I first got there, that was the first thing I noticed.  The 2nd thing was they don't have lots of equipment! We got there there weren't even that many people there and had to wait like 30 mins because they were short staffed AND because there weren't enough of the pulley clip thing you use to spot each other with.  The people that did help us out were nice though so at least that helped a little.Other than that, I did get quite a workout with my arms and legs.  It was fun because we had a group of 4 of us but I don't think I'll be back to this location.  Thankfully one groupon can be used with 2 people so we'll probably head to the Upland location next time.

This is a very small place. The first thing I noticed walking in was the foul smell. The walls and rocks are pretty old and the rocks are extremely slippery. The ropes are attached to the top such that there is not as much friction, making it very difficult to belay someone who is heavier. The weight helps a little but it is a hassle having to lug it around.I think the bouldering routes are fun but the top rope routes are not very accurate in terms of level because I can climb the 10s easily.I do like the slab wall which is very good for footwork training.

2013 UPDATE:Hangar 18 is a smaller gym, but they work with their spacing the best that they can - and for this I am very grateful.With the new additions to the gym,  it is clear that the owner and managers are making efforts to keep their customers satisfied.New additions include:   adding weekly classes,   a beautiful new floor,   a sequestered weights areaThe following issues have been rectified:  1) Floor - Has been completely replaced. It is new and clean.  2) Mats - Are also slowly being replaced.  4) Routes - turnaround is getting better.  5) Ventilation - TBD - summer is coming.  6) Sound system - don't know if they made any repairs to this, but its decent at the moment.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~1/23/12 UPDATE:DEAR OWNERS: Please tend to this Hangar 18 with the same care and consideration that you do their other Hangar 18 gyms. Hire staff to clean the gym thoroughly once a week (deep clean shampoo of the floors and bathrooms), replace the floor pads and mats, hire route setters for this gym who know how to properly rate routes (there was a V1 route that was actually a V3).~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~2011 UPDATE:The first place I ever started climbing was at Hangar 18 (aka Beach City Rocks), and so this place has a special place in my heart. However, this was over 3 years ago. Since then I have gone out into the world and seen other gyms. I am sad to say that Hangar 18 is a hot, smelly mess.Issues are as follows:1) Floor - is in utter disrepair. There are various tears in the mats, so if you land in them you risk spraining and shattering your ankle or foot simultaneously. In the past three years I can only recall one section of the mat being replaced. So, just think about this: 3 years of feet and sweaty climbing on these floors.2) Mats - lumpy, flat or so stiff that you can sprain your ankle on them.As of 1/23/13, there are at least 6 VERY LARGE tears in the floor. Walking on them alone is bound to twist ones ankle.3) Ropes - old. I have to use a house gri-gri because my Gri-Gri2 cannot accommodate the ropes once they begin breaking down on the inside (which causes lumps in the rope)4) Routes - slow turnaround.There are some routes in the back wall that have been set for over 6 months now.5) Ventilation - on hot days this place is a sauna. They used to have a fan in the back, but it has long since been broken and no one has tried to fix it.6) Sound system - intermittent in the back of the gym. If anything, this is indicative of how management has not taken the time to make repairs.7) Anchors - the floor used to have rope anchors for pairs of climbers that were composed of one large and one small person. Now we have to vie for the single counter-weight, "Wally".  8) Bathroom/Locker rooms - are dusty and the floors are filthy.Pros 1) Staff - very friendly and willing to help in any way possible.2) Climbers - very friendly and willing to help in any way possible.The sole reason I keep coming to this gym are the two Pro-reasons (and why I gave this place 1 star). So, if you don't mind poor climbing conditions, then feel free to come here. But, if you do, you will meet some amazing and talented people.I beseech management to please tend to this Hangar 18 with the same care and consideration that they do their other Hangar 18 gyms. Hire staff to clean the gym thoroughly once a week (deep clean shampoo of the floors and bathrooms), replace the floor pads and mats, hire route setters for this gym who know how to properly rate routes (there was a V1 route that was actually a V3).

I went on a Saturday evening with my brother and two guy friends. The service at the front desk was not great: we filled out the forms when we walked in and then they didn't tell us what to do after. It was our first time there so i assumed they would guide us through, give us our equipment if needed. But we ended up just standing there waiting for fifteen minutes or more until they finally asked us if we'd been helped...so i told them we were waiting and asked them if we needed shoes or anything and the dude's reply was, "well yeah..you have to pay!" -.- come on bro..so they didn't really help us at all and we just did our own thing.It cost us 19 dollars just for bouldering and shoes...not terrible.I wish the gym was larger with more walls. I expected a much larger area, but oh well i had funI recommend going in the morning or in the evening so that you don't have to deal with all the bodies.. there are lots of people and it can start to smell like feet haha!

Great place to go and learn the ropes of how to climb. Our instructor was patient with us. Since it was both of are first time. He made sure we got it,  and made sure we understood the importance of the knots in the ropes and effective communication back and forth. They watch from a distance but when they seen us having a difficult time, they were right there to guide us. Give us a few more pointers. Great place to go and it really works out your full body.

Great indoor rock climbing spot near LA. The instructors help you with your harnesses and safety equipment and are very available throughout the day to help whenever you need it. There are a few easy courses and a lot of advanced ones, but I wish there were a few more for mid-level rock climbers. I do like that they have a Bouldering section where you just climb up without a harness and can sit on top and enjoy the view! The location is very near Manhattan Beach, so my friends and I usually go hang out there to relax after a long day of rock climbing.
install a mofockin water fountain please people :)other than that, i realllly dig this spot :)

I'm seeing some negative reviews about this place but most are from whiners so i had to leave my two cents and set the record straight.  I came here with a friend for my first ever climb.  I'm not an expert climber, in fact the only things I've climbed on to in the past decade are my bed and my couch.  I came with a super-sporty friend of mine to pass some time, have some fun and get some exercise; needless to say, we accomplished all three.  I also found the people who attend this gym to be the most friendly, outgoing and helpful folks I've ever met in Los Angeles.  They were so cool in fact, it took me a few minutes to get used to how nice they were.  I've seen people complaining about how small this place is, how it has an offensive odor and how the holds are too old and slippery and even that the floor mats are too old. To them i say: STOP WHINING.  gosh!  If you're really that posh then go climb somewhere else and it'll just be me and the friendly cool people.  It's a gym, built in a warehouse, so it's going to stink a bit, as long as this place has been around you shouldn't be surprised.  The holds are fine, you're going to tell me that if you go climbing out in the real world that all your holds are going to be peachy? They aren't going to be in the least bit slippery or hard to grasp?  SHUT UP!  The floor mats are fine, at least they were when i went there, if you have a problem with them then don't fall on them. This isn't the poshest gym in town, I would admit that, but it's probably the coolest and closest knit bunch of people you'll find. If you're one of those "professional" climbers who can't deal with people who don't know what "crimpy" means, or can't stand climbing around a few newbies then i'd recommend going pretty much anywhere else.  But if you're looking for a good time at a pretty darn good price then you've come to the right place.

My friend and I used my Groupon for this place this past weekend and while we had a great time and got some laughs out of it, I won't be becoming a regular any time soon. Basically, if you're even a little afraid of rock climbing, don't count of anyone who works here to make you feel safer or more at ease. If, however, you are a total badass who can skitter up the side of a mountain like a possessed spider monkey, then you'll do just fine. Neither myself nor my friend are quite like that, but I definitely saw people here who are.As far as experiences go, this was a fun one, but mostly because of the company (and I provided THAT). I was helped out by two different guys, and both of them had a laid back and (in the case of our instructor) a slightly irritated demeanor. I did get frustrated by some of the mysterious choices my instructor made... like not mentioning that my friend could clip herself into the ground with a strap built into the flooring to keep her from flying up in the air when I was descending (she's about 1/2 my size) until it had already happened... or when he had us start on a 5.10 graded wall instead of the very easiest wall they had. His response was "I have my reasons". Well, they are mysterious...

The establishment itself is awesome. A few friends and I decided to check this place out after coming across the groupon deal. The only issue I have is the customer service. The instructor Corinna is not very friendly and quite condescending. Had it not been for the fact that we were all in a great mood and excited first time climbers we would have definitely escalated a complaint against her. I would recommend this establishment however if you are a novice try not to deal with her.

Visited Hangar 18 on a free open night.  I was super impressed by the friendly/ enthusiastic staff and the amount of walls they have there.  Jeremy a super experienced worker there who has been there for 6+ years balley-ed us for the night.  Super nice guy and was very helpful.Only complaint is that a lot of people started taking off shirts and socks.  The smell in the warehouse started getting a bit sweaty for my taste.  I wish that they made it a point to tell the climbers to keep their clothes on.  Other then that clean facilities, lots of range for different levels of experience.  Fun for all ages.  I saw little kids climbing up the free climb wall, crazy fast.

I've been coming here for a while and I love it but to all you noobs....-Top rope climbing is pretty safe in a gym which is why the staff are so non-chalant while you are panicking. Hangar 18 requires an auto locking device so you'll only drop a foot or so if your buddy lets go of the rope.You might bump a knee or scrape yourself but that's it so stop crying. Honestly it just makes the staff more ambivalent and they're ambivalent enough. -PARENTS PLEASE SUPERVISE YOUR SMALL CHILDREN. I almost made a pancake out of a pretty 6 year old. The staff make miserable babysitters and they aren't changing so it's up to you to keep your kid alive. 150+lb humans are dropping from 15' up in the air. -Indoor bouldering is a high-injury sport. Pads add to the danger. Falling incorrectly, not quite on the pad, between seams causes many ankle/leg injuries. -Plenty of (skilled) females climb here so I don't feel outnumbered by the guys. And new guys, don't get all sullen if the 5' skinny girl can outclimb you. She's just better than you.-There is climbing etiquette. Mostly - Don't hog a route/wall. Pay attention to the people around you. Are any of them working on the same wall? If so, you take turns. When it isn't your turn or you are checking out a route step back so that others can climb. If you fall/touch the floor/use the wrong handhold your turn is over. -People are very focused on their training so they aren't as friendly and climbers don't give info unless asked. If you want to know something ask someone who's resting or waiting for their turn.

Let's start off with the good.  $35 a month for membership is hard to beat.  Most of the newer climbing gyms in Socal like Sender 1 charge at least twice as much.  This location caters to boulders so the bouldering routes are decent and get changed fairly regularly.  Now for the bad.  It's a fairly small space and can get uncomfortably packed.  It doesn't help that they regularly do Groupon specials bringing in large groups of newbies with no clue about climbing gym etiquette.  Basic stuff like not walking underneath a climber who may fall on you.  The lead climbing routes infrequently get changed out, were talking months with no new routes.  They also spray paint old holds to put up new routes.  I'm all for recycling, but pulling on slick painted holds is in no way enjoyable.  This may seem harsh, but a number of the more experienced climbers here, especially sport climbers have left for other gyms.  If it weren't for the fact that I have good friends that still climb here I'd leave too.  While Hangar can't match other gyms for sheer size they can compete by offering a more quality experience.  I sincerely hope management will read this and consider stepping up their game.About me: H18 member 2+ years, experienced outdoor climber (trad, sport, bouldering).

The overall vibe at this gym is grey, dull and the staff is cold and will ridicule you for no real reason. Routes do no feel contemplated or perfected by route setters. Uninspired to say the least. The bouldering is better. It's more of a boulderers gym than a sport climbers gym to be honest. There are some really nice people who go here regularly so there is a very small community to get to know but it sort of gets weighed out by the hounding staffers. Sorry you guys. Some of you are pretty sweet but there are few of your colleagues who get pretty weird with people and feel the need to prove themselves beyond what is appropriate.  I miss my gym back in Arizona. Rocks and Ropes I never knew how good you were until I started training in LA. Bleht.

Yes I am a fan because this is the only rock gym I have been going to. I'm a glass half full kinda gal so there's really no complaints since becoming a member this past May.  True: it does get packed on a week night especially on Tuesdays and Thursdays.  The smell of feet, sweat, rubber and ego make this place a rockin' party for bacteria and thus would probably help if you carried a sanitizer for your feet IF you're renting shoes.  I get the work out that I need done and have encountered zero problem with people hogging up walls to work on problems.  People are pretty mindful and respectful: if you fall or complete a problem, your turn is over, on to the next person waiting.   I've also found people to be pretty helpful both either asking for pointers or them just lending a hand.  They put up new holds and some new problems around the gym so it's a new challenge.  Coming here, having fun, not being so self conscious about all the muscle staring you in the face and having a workout agenda going is a great start and end to a work out.

Pay VERY close attention to the contract you are signing with this place. I bought a 3 month promotional membership for $69 during the holiday season. I went to the gym and it was small and overcrowded and there were only 2 or 3 auto-belay's and I was by myself since I just moved to the area. The crowdedness made it slow to climb. I should have bought a day-pass before purchasing the membership, but to make things worse, after my 3 month membership was up (and to repeat I only went to the gym once) they automatically charged me a one month membership fee without giving me a reminder notice. The charges were pending on my card so I called right away and asked to cancel my membership and was told I couldn't do it over the phone. I had to email the owner. I emailed the owner and it took him about a week to respond. He told me he would cancel the membership, but would not reimburse me the money even if I was not going to use his gym. He made it sound like he was doing me a favor by offering to put the month membership onto a gift card so I could use it later. That obviously wasn't the point since I just wanted my money refunded. I was really disappointed about the way they do business and I don't recommend going there.

If you love rock-climbing and are laid back then this place is right in your wheel-house.My lady and I came as guests of two members of the gym and had a fun time, though we had some reservations. We both are moderately experienced with rock climbing, so we knew what we were getting into.::SERVICE::Probably the most troubling aspect of the place so I'll get it out of the way first. The staff seemed REALLY tired or bored or ... something. They were more than willing to get us checked in and get some equipment for us but the enthusiasm was lacking. Maybe they were all at a staff meeting the night before, went out to a bar afterwards, and were really hungover.Not sure if this should be included in this section, but for lack of a better place here it is. It's very easy to climb here compared to other gyms. We just had to sign a waiver and that was it. We didn't need to prove we knew how to belay (we do, in case that frightened you) and we pretty much could walk right in and do whatever we wanted without supervision. It was really convenient for us, but if you're inexperienced then you might be left in the lurch.::FACILITY::If you've been to other rock climbing gyms (Planet Granite or the like) this place might surprise you a bit. This place is JUST rock climbing. They have one, and exactly one pull up bar/dips combo machine and a few free weights that are flippantly left in the corner covered in chalk. If you like going to these places to climb but also do other stuff, you'll be let down.The bathrooms have a shower which gets the job done. They're pretty small but clean overall.::THE ROCKS::The impression I got was that everything was old. The colors of the holds were often faded, making it difficult to tell where your next hold was. The routes on the walls would drift into areas of other paths, making it really likely two climbers would get in each others' way. On two occasions a hold moved in my hand, which probably isn't good (but I am a bigger guy, 230 lbs, so it may not be relevant). The difficulty ratings of the courses seemed a bit off as well. Routes ranked very easy would be rather challenging while others ranked a bit harder were a cinch.The bouldering is definitely the best part of the gym. The routes are fun and dynamic and there are a ton of them. If you're big on bouldering you'll like this place a lot.Overall we DID have a good time here, but this does not strike me as a place to go if it's your first time as there isn't much in the way of coddling. If you're going to go, then get some experienced friends and give it a shot.

I have been climbing here for about a month now, and have been having a fantastic time at hangar 18. The employees are extremely helpful to a gumby like me. I would highly recommend the intermediate bouldering class with Justin ($20 with membership). He really took the time to teach me the basics and give me the tools to improve my climbing technique on my own time. If you are looking into getting started climbing in Los Angeles, hangar 18s price point and classes are very hard to beat

First time here and last! This place smells like dirty socks /gym stuffy . It does not esthetically pleasing either.The upstairs "party" area is old and dirty with a step that needs to be clearly marked! I tripped several times. Plus no privacy for u and ur party. This place is not kid friendly either. Guess the folks that work here never were kids!
Brought a date here.  It was her first time rock climbing.  The staff was very helpful and patient with her.  We had a blast!

okay seriously.  right now i'm locked into 33 bucks a month.  how anyone in my situation could rate this less than five stars is crazy.  to the critics i urge you to take a step back, maybe visit Sender One or another new, state of the art gym.  obviously the big gyms are better overall for lots of reasons, but they also cost 80 buck a month with around a 40 dollar initiation fee....okay thats greedy in my opinion.  so the big gym ends up being 550-600 dollar more expensive than hangar 18.  im not saying i wouldn;t join a bigger gym if it were closer to where i live....the full fitness center and huge walls are tempting, i bet even people that work for hangar 18 will tell you that.  but for what they are, i think hangar 18 does a hell of a job.  i recently tried a couple of the yoga and fitness classes they offer to members free.  both instructors - brianna and ivan were really friendly and professional and held great workouts.  they also seem to have a solid system for putting up new routes and since i go alot i always have the option of going to long beach or another branch to get on all new climbs.  i guess my point is that it is unfair to compare hangar 18 to these big modern gyms, especially if you join at the right time when the price is low.   take the 600 bucks you save and buy a rack or a crashpad or whatever.

My husband and I were moving to the area and since we love climbing, we wanted to get a membership somewhere nearby. I saw that Hangar 18 had a sweet Groupon deal on memberships and even though I read the reviews, I still bought it. HUGE MISTAKE. I'd read how awful the routes were, how unsafe the facility was, how unhelpful the staff is, but I figured "it can't really be that bad, and for a membership this cheap, it's worth it!" How wrong I was. They don't double wrap the top ropes, so good luck belaying anyone heavier than you. If they fall, you're going flying. They spray paint the holds, making them slippery and impossible to grip. The routes themselves are rated completely incorrectly, and must be designed by someone completely inept. I'm a 5'7" female, and if I can't reach the holds for a basic, beginner level route, something is wrong. The facility is disgusting and is clearly not well maintained. The staff is usually preoccupied with their phones and do nothing about unsafe behavior going on in the gym. The renal equipment is all old and barely functioning. There are so many small things that they could change and it would make the entire experience so much better. But no one at the facility cares enough to make the changes. TL;DR Don't make my mistake. It may be cheap, but it's not worth it.

Took a group of friends climbing today. The place was packed, but we got help reasonably quick. Their sign up system in the computers is a little slow and annoying, but once you get through that the workers are helpful. Great instruction, lots of different levels Of climbs. A little crazy at times with so many people, but no one got hurt ;) we had a great time!

U see the Groupon affect...can get very crowded and equipment sometimes wet with previous sweat. ..yuk...guys purchase your own rockclimbing shoes bcuz the free rental shoes r nasty  (learned my lesson a few times) got a great deal at 5 10 a rockclimbing store

What the hell happened to this place?! Packed, really dirty, the floors are coming out and tripping people, and not enough crash pads/really old crash pads with no cushion. Wheres the safety?! Obviously not here. Yea you may have soft gym floors but I still wouldnt want to land on that if I were in the cave climbing with my back to the floor. Wow. Came here to boulder and it seems like they havent changed the routes in a long time because tapes for routes were either missing or some crap like that. I guess I need to find a different climbing gym in LA.

I've climbed (recreationally) before, but by the time I showed up at Hangar 18 so many years had passed that I had pretty much forgotten everything I learned.   Hangar 18 makes it really easy to  start climbing right away.  I went with someone who had been climbing regularly, so he got me up to speed really quickly.  They have lots of different courses, although some of the "easier" ones seemed harder than the more intermediate ones.  I also like that they have a contraption where you can belay yourself if you're not climbing with someone else.  The bouldering area is pretty big, although it seems like they need a few more big mats under that area.  Yeah, it's a gym and people sweat in it, so of course it doesn't smell like a spa, and it's not pristine clean.  But that just helps weed out the whiners.  Pricing for rentals and climbing are really affordable, and it's nice not to have to worry about finding parking.  The staff was helpful and seemed pretty hands off unless you went up to them and specifically asked for something.  I went on a Saturday during the daytime, and there were lots of kids but their parents seemed to do a good job at keeping them well behaved.

Andre was the staff member who was working when my friend and I showed up for my very first session of rock climbing. He was very knowledgeable and didn't speak to me like I was an idiot (even though I really felt like one)  during the lesson. I think it was $30 or something but we nearly spent an hour getting the harness to fit right, learning the verbal commands, set up of the belay, and how to use the belay. He did leave us to practice knots and checking gear but came right back as we thought we were ready to move onto the next step. His timing was impeccable and he was very kind. Once my friend and I began our climbing Andre stood there and helped us until we were comfortable to do it on our own. He also explained why things were done a certain way without me having to ask why.I went back the next week and found that the rental shoes with the velcro weren't as comfortable as the laced ones, they were really slippery. Only to see at the end of my session that there wasn't any grip on the toes and I could see quite a few layers into the shoe. =( Next time I'll have to check the rental shoes before hand and look into investing in some shoes and a harness of my own. Thanks HANGAR18, now you won't be able to get rid of me!
bring a water bottle, get some chalk for your hands (will strongly help), leggings or shorts have fun !

Bought a groupon, even with the discount, I was disappointed.When I was a tween, I went to a summer camp that would take us rock climbing.  It was lead by a bunch of college students and we always had a blast.  In my best effort to re-live those days my girlfriend and I bought a groupon.  We called ahead, and Hanger 18 told us just to show up whenever so we did.  We didn't really except that while we received our lesson from some guy who was extremely short towards us, he would also be walking around giving lessons to several other groups.  He gave us our shoes, 15 minutes later he gave us our harness, 15 minutes later showed us how to use them, each step took forever.  Plus, he wasn't very patience and since I am very stupid, patience would have been helpful.   We finally started climbing, which was fun.  My girlfriend went first and she told the guy, "I am scared I will fall."  He replied, "Don't worry, everyone falls at some point."  That wasn't the reassurance she needed at that moment.   I would only go back if I was going with someone who knew what they were doing and we didn't need any help from people working there.

STAY AWAY!  You're a broken/twisted ankle/knee away from having a really bad visit to this death trap.Pro Tip! If you bring your kids, keep an eye on them (PRO-pro tip: keep both eyes on them and stay within 10 feet) so they don't get squashed by a climber who is too focused to give a hoot about what's underneath him/her besides a spotter/mat and a safe landing.  This is actually more dangerous for the climber than the child (fun fact: kids are made of rubber and tend to bounce), because it can lead to serious injury if a proper fall is interrupted.Okay, on to the review.  Ahem...This place is getting really run down.  The mats are in laughably bad condition and they refuse to fix them or acknowledge it is a safety hazard.  They even have a spot marked with "Place Pad Here" on the floor where it is virtually non-existent.  I landed really hard in* one of those dead spots (read: concrete) on Sunday and I could feel the vibration all the way up to my pelvis.  I was extemely lucky to walk away uninjured, though my hip bothered me a little later that day.  Needless to say I stay away from that section now.Also, they take FOREVER to set new routes.  Get ready to be stuck climbing the same damn climbs over and over and over and over and over....I remember when this place used to be cool and management seemed to care.  Now they can't even take the time to refill the paper towel dispensers in the bathroom, let alone fix/replace the mats.  Shampooing the dirty floor is another great idea.Do not visit this establishment if you want to be safe and/or have a good time.Lastly, I don't feel like I'm asking for much here.  A safe, fun and clean environment that attends to the needs of its clientele is not impossible to achieve.*This is not a grammar mistake nor a typo; I intentionally used "in" and not "on" because my foot literally sank through the cracks in the mat, landing on the concrete below.  Thankfully I didn't shatter my heel.P.S. I was angrier when I first drafted this.  You're welcome for toning it down.

Hangar 18 is a great gym. I live in West L.A. just down the street from another rock climbing gym, but I make the trek to Hawthorne to go to this one because I like it much better. The vibe here is low key, not competitive or jockish. The employees are nice, helpful and knowledgeable people. Parking couldn't be easier. I always leave feeling happy that I came and glad that I bought a membership. I've seen beginners and experts, six-year olds and sixty-plus year olds, English speakers and those who don't speak any English here. All seeming to fully enjoy themselves. Hangar 18 doesn't require that you pay for their exclusive classes before they allow you to climb. They offer tons of help and classes if you want, but if you know what you are doing they encourage you to do your thing. Looking forward to going there tomorrow!

pretty decent place to play around.... i mean its kinda hard to find some good places in LA right?  theres always UCI's gym or go to Inland Empire to find plenty more.Small Warehouse place but fits the formations inside.  So I saw an schedule, and this place has yoga and other activities too.  Signing up for gym membership is pretty expensive but worth the fun sports addiction than the regular robot treadmill experience.  One whole day of rock climbing I think is like only $16! + $5 for equipment and shoes.  Of course, if you've never gone here before you definitely they to pay for the initial introduction course.... its crucial, its life or death man hahaAlso! You need a partner thats around the same weight as you perferably because they're going to your safety or you're going to be their safety.  Pretty scary because it requires alot of trust, so take the time to learn details.  Other than than its a pretty chill environment.  Hear it gets pretty crowded on weekday nights, so always give them a call.Location: Pretty tricky because its a warehouse looking place hidden inside.  Its around industrial/business area so just look for a section of blue mid-tall buildings and HAVE FUN!!! =)- remember to wear socks haha- this place is better for adults, don't bring your kids... its annoying, unless you're a super great parent then I'm assuming they are as disciplined obedient and respectful as you ;)

I've been a member here for over a year and I've been a member at gyms in Boston & NJ so I've seen how other gyms do it and I've always respected their systems.Here is my perspective:It's a fun gym with a good vibe and fun routes & problems. That being said, over the last year the user experience has been on the decline.There is no education provided to new climbers. If you don't believe me, go up to someone who is wearing socks under their climbing shoes and ask them if they've been explained climbing rules or etiquette. The gym has become overcrowded with people who don't know the rules. Hangar18 does a Groupon every 3 months and their goal is to get as many people through that door as possible, which I totally understand. The problem is, they do little-nothing to explain the rules to the new clients or educate them about gym etiquette.  Newcomers are climbing everywhere and most don't even understand the concepts of following routes/problems, which is very important for the safety of others. If you're going to scale up your membership, scale up your staff to accommodate.Just yesterday I watched 5 newcomers coming off the rock uncontrolled, at least 4 times, nearly hitting 3 different experienced climbers who I know to be members for longer than me. The new guys didn't even seem to know or care they were putting others at risk.Kids' parties happen all day long on the weekends, which I also understand. And I also understand those kids can't be reasoned with. But the staff needs to take 15 minutes and explain to the ADULTS that these kids need to be supervised and not playing tag as climbers unpredictable fall to the ground around them. It's dangerous to the kids and the climbers. Recently, there have been injuries, prompting management to draw a cartoon stick figure on a dry erase board, depicting what can happen if people don't 'watch out' or spot each other. I would hope management takes a more serious approach than that.

Maybe I overthink it, but I usually find myself in mid-boulder climb thinking "where the eff is the next hold?!", look around wildly, arms get tired so I drop down, and lastly think "I need to better plan my route.. AGAIN". And this goes with pretty much most routes I try here. Maybe I'm spoiled by Rockreation. Maybe I just suck. Or maybe the people who create these routes suck more. The latter was the consensus my sister and I came to when she visited a couple weekends ago.What makes it confusing first of all is that the color of the tape AND the holds determines the route. This confused the hell out of me my first day when I'm wondering why the hell yellow taped routes were going in every which direction. And then the placement of some of them, well the designer must've had spider limbs. One route my sister was plastered against the wall: legs and arms stretched to capacity with her face pressed up against a hold right in her way (chalk face!) and trying to shimmy her weight to one side which took what felt like forever. The entire time I'm standing there thinking this ain't right!This place also seems overrun by kids and teenagers, maybe it's Groupon and it's overselling membership deal. I came one Friday early afternoon and I literally was the oldest one there.. don't you people have school?! No real workout equipment like the other climbing gyms I've been to and with a crappy run-down locker room.I'll be back unfortunately, darn you Groupon and your 2 month membership.. which I bought 2 of!

LOVE this place! I got a Groupon deal as a gift which you can find easily for Hangar 2 month passes for like $60 which is great! It is somewhat busy of a location but cant blame em. For beginners there arent many paths to climb, maybe two with the assisted pullys, but once you get the hang of it the bouldering, scalling, and free climbing is the best. By the time I was getting near the end of my month pass i had gotten really good! Now im a rock climbing addict and fan and need another pass ASAP.  Shoe rental comes with membership and chalk (useful) is sold there.

I've been to this gym several times when it used to be Beach City Rocks.  I came here a few weeks ago for a friend's birthday.  I was excited to go experience the "new" Hanger 18 gym, but was somewhat disappointed when I got there and realized that it really didn't change much.  I only had higher expectations because all of the other Hanger 18 gyms (especially the Riverside one) have new, clean holds and well marked climbing problems.  I remember BCR as a gym with very confusing markings and that standard did not really change even when it got converted into a Hanger 18.  On a positive note, the staff at the front desk was very friendly and that always makes a great first impression.  I do not like rope climbing so I can't say much about the party staff, but they seemed knowledgable and helpful.  I stuck with my beloved bouldering and like the fact that they do have problems that allow manteling which does somewhat mimic the outdoors.  All in all, a good day in the climbing gym!  I haven't climbed for many months prior to this, but I still have a lot of climber in me :)

VERDICT: cost effective local rock gym where the easy routes are hard and the hard climbs are easy; i don't get it either.QUALIFIER: well, the influx of new membership brought on by groupon discounts just feeds the crowds of local occasional wannabe climbers. watch out for those sprawling afterschool day care kids; they get in the way running around in circles. there's less open space than rockreation in LA.SERVICE: no water fountain!?!

I walked in to Hangar 18 over the weekend with some of my friends thinking rocking climbing would be fun.  I walked out with my tail tucked in between my legs.  Hangar 18 kicked my butt.  When you first go in, you do notice the smell.  But after you've been there for a while you get used to it and don't even notice it.  The rock climbing shoes you get here remind me of the kinds you get at the bowling alley, or the ice skating rink.  Used by millions.  Germy.  But, Hangar 18 does a great job at spraying it to make it smell better.  And the shoes are pretty new.Rock Climbing was fun.  It's actually more fun when you go with someone, instead of going by yourself.  I was even able to belay my friends down the rock wall.  Is that what it's called?  If you go by yourself, there is an auto-belayer.  Or you can just try going up the boulders.How was the rock climbing?  Hard!  And it didn't help that we had to go so high up on the wall. There were many thoughts that would go through my head while I was climbing up.   Things like... 1) So this is what being Spiderman feels like.  2) What happens if I fall?  3) Wow this is very high. And, most reoccurring thought: 4) Oh shit I'm gonna die!!!!! The next couple of days after my forearms were OUT.  They were dead to the world.  You don't realize how much you're using it when you're hanging on for dear life.   Don't worry, you won't fall to your death.  It just feels that way.If you go, I would recommend you bring some chalk because your hands WILL get sweaty... and you don't want to be grabbing onto rocks with sweaty palms.Parking: they have a pretty big parking lot in what looks like an industrial area.
I liked climbing here, I got the groupon - $30 for unlimited climbing for 2. I'd recommend going earlier in the day as the gym fills up around 5pm.

So far it's the nicest and coolest gym I've ever been to. Mind you that I've only been climbing since March, 2011. It's got a lot of bouldering and top roping. There is a wide range of difficulty as far as the routes go. It's a nice place that usually doesn't smell funky and they also play some music. The people there both that go there to climb and the staff are all friendly and great people. I came here once in late december of 2010 and I was instantly hooked. I immediately bought a groupon for a year and try to go as often as work and life permits.

I've been climbing here for years. This address and location 4926 Rosecrans was one of the first indoor rock gyms in Los Angeles. Built in 1996, the walls are older and the cement / stucco layer to cover the wood is decent  enough for some smearing if you want to waste good shoes indoors. As you walk in the front door you are immediately faced with the lead climbing cave. Before you can see the remaining lead / top rope walls on the south side of the building you have the two main boulders. On the north side of the building you have more top rope walls. Hangar has 4 True Blue Auto Belays installed for most of the year.If climbing doesn't kill you, the legal work will.Before you can walk deeper into the gym you must sign, or have a legal liability waiver signed for you if you are under the age of 18. If you have a computer, fill it out on the website before you even show up, saves you about 30 minutes. If you don't do the waivers online before you get there you must sign one off the iPad they have set up to use. After the waiver is finished, a quick explanation of indoor climbing is force fed to you either before or after you fill out an "Orientation Process." The things they explain to you are literally written on this second form you must complete. After those are signed all you will need to do is show up wearing clothes, because they have everything else you will need. They will help you size your shoes or harness pretty quick. Did the legal work kill you? Did you read anything?After you hopefully understand what you are about to do, you are asked:"What would you like to do?"Membership is on a month to month cycle and you can cancel at anytime. Check their website for a discount, the normal membership is around $50 a month. If you are just visiting for the day it's just $16 admission. Hangar 18 is a chain, so you have your choice of different walls to climb if you want to drive in Southern California traffic for climbing gyms.Maybe you can handle climbing in and around some of the birthday parties / boy scout events they offer. The weekends can be decent if you know what boulder problem you want to fall off of again, or already have your friends to climb with. The staff usually is in survival mode again dealing with these parties or individual Group-On users. But these tend to be on the weekends, and so do you! Good luck. At a certain point the size of a group will just make the gym a very loud room to be in. They can to deal with some bigger group parties from time to time, so for a quiet date maybe ask if there is a boy scout party or something planned at the same time. Avoid those! If you have a day off, and go Mon-Fri anytime before 2pm you have a climbing gym almost to yourself. After work and school the members will mostly come in when the climbing team shows up to practice. Around 5 you will start to see some stronger kids who climb very well when they only weigh about 60 pounds. The team is great and the people are really friendly.The gym is nearby where I live, and if the traffic starts to move it can be a 15 minute drive from the beach down Rosecrans. Surfs up!

Though I may be a little biased, I love coming to this gym. Anyone that is there to CLIMB instead of SOCIALIZE will find that the facility is exactly what one would need (minus a few minor details here and there as with any other business).Bouldering routes are supposed to be really technical and challenging so when I see reviews on how you have too difficult of a time completing one, it isn't the route, it's your technical skills. Hangar 18 has a staff that REALLY knows how to climb and climb well so of course they're going to challenge you to do your best.As far as the customer service goes, I can agree with the majority when they say that some of the men that work there (one in particular) are extremely short and lack enthusiasm when dealing with customers. But I understand their lack of energy when you see them having to deal with 60 kids at a time trying to teach them how to climb.

Really LA? Really? I came here after reading several reviews that this was one of the best places to rock climb in SoCal. I'm from the North Bay (i.e. San Francisco) and I have to say, we got it WAYYYYY better up north.Hangar 18 is a tiny little rock gym. It is overpriced and fairly dirty. All the mats are worn down, and there isn't much place for them either as everything is very cramped and butted up against each other. In fact, some of the mats were literally torn open and their filling was just all over the place. There isn't a lot of space to walk around without the possibility of someone dropping on top of you. There isn't a lot of seating or cubbies to store your stuff. None of the paths seemed fully finished or properly labeled. I'd read the tape saying to follow yellow rocks with white tape... but there were no yellow rocks with white tape. There didn't seem to be any finish zones either, sometimes the rocks just stopped halfway up with no clear sense of direction. Am I done? Do I dyna up on half these problems? Do i just make my own path?I only went bouldering since I was just myself, but there was some belay action going on, however it didn't look that exciting. Walls were maybe 2 or 3 stories at best? The places I used to go were at least twice as tall as here, and more varied. The bouldering and the belay walls were kept in separate areas where I used to frequent unlike here. Like I said earlier, very cramped, you could probably jump from the bouldering area to the wall if you wanted.The staff was friendly, though I really couldn't tell who was staff and who were just enthusiastic regulars. Maybe I've just been spoiled by the likes of Planet Granite in Sunnyvale and San Francisco, which feel easily 5x larger. But even still, I'd expect more for less. This place needs a complete overhaul, maybe become strictly bouldering and revamp how they label their problems. Drop the day pass price by 5 bucks and maybe I'd consider coming back.If you get a deal, I could see it being okay for a quick fix. Do yourself a favor LA, check out the Planet Granite facilities if you ever travel north, and you will be blown away. Makes Hangar 18 look like a shack. Sorry for all the hate 18, but you just don't scream "On Belay!" to me.To those who aren't familar (as I saw these complaints in other reviews), being barefoot and shirtless in a rock climbing gym is very common. Try not to be intimidated by the many lean muscle people displaying their abs and arm muscles, just comes with the territory. There will always be a small hint of stink from sweat and feet, but if the gym takes care of itself, they should be cleaning their floors every night. Dunno if this place does... but certainly looked dirty.

3.5 Stars...I've been rock climbing before and this was my first time here. For first timers, rock climbing is a fun and definitely challenging workout! It just takes as sec to get going as you fill out waivers, get shoes then sit through a lesson on how not to fall (can be lengthy but pay attention so you don't get hurt!)Can get very busy and cramped on weekends esp. with the GrouponA lot of people mentioned it smells but to me it's like being in a ice skating rink or a bowling alley. Stay away if it's that's not for you! =)The staff... This is an interesting one...the previous reviews hit the nail on the head. During your visit you might feel like you're bothering them or that they want to be ANYWHERE else other than here with you and even unenthusiastic but they kinda warm up and become a little less weird after that. Kinda...They have parties here for all ages! Sounds like funJust an fyi, if you're belaying for someone larger than you on the more difficult climbs, the white cylindrical thing on the floor (Wally Watermelon) is what you're supposed to attach yourself to on the harder climbs so you don't flying into the air if you're starting out  All in all, not for the faint of heart but if you are adventurous I definitely recommend a try and keep in mind the above points :)

I have a membership here and this is my main climbing gym. My friends and I have been here for me half a year, and for them much longer. For a climbing gym, it really should be unacceptable for the setting to change only once or twice a year. I have had memberships at other gyms in other parts of the country, and nowhere else have the cycling of new climbs been nearly so deplorable. You should be making new sets on any of the walls, at least one of the walls, at least once a month. The stronger climbers regularly complain of how bored and uninspired they are when the same climbs have gone unchanged for so long. How do you not have a water fountain at a gym? The owners need to focus more on maintaining this gym and less on collecting new ones.

My rating is is based on the initial customer service of one of the workers there. Not only is it emphasized that it's dangerous, but the short Asian dude gave zero f**ks about really helping you through the knot tying or harness portion. I don't know if it's a scare tactic or just lack of enthusiasm for his job. I would have appreciated a warmer greeting to this activity as it was my first time. It made it less appealing to try again. Or at least at this location. Maybe if I was the cute blonde he kept wandering to and giggling with when I was practicing, I would have felt better about climbing safely. I was scared to death! The instructor once at the wall was more understanding of a new person, so I give a three rating. The first guy deserves a 0. I only make specific comments on who is n case they ever actually check these and can use it for training purposes. If you want better numbers as far as new business the first impression is key. That guy was terrible and had my date not already paid I would have walked out immediately. No one has time for bs when trying to be active.

I came here for the first time for a friend's birthday and loved it. . This place was great and so was the staff. The instructors were really friendly and gave great directions. There were times where I was stuck and didn't know what direction to go and the instructor screamed out, "step on the blue one on your bottom left!" I listened and reached the top.  Lots of fun but the place does get crowded and the walls are filled with climbers. I definitely have to go back for more climbing action.

I love this place.  I'm addicted to the four autobelays!  I've been climbing for 9 years and have a plethora of climbing partners, but I can't get around how easy it is to pop in for quick runs up and down routes on the autobelays.  Love it.  Plus the routes are fun and the staff is friendly.

couldn't get passed the smell of shoes AND feet! the places are small and overall not a good value for your dollar. The employees look bored and were NOT the slightest bit helpful. Was not impressed at all and probably won't go back.

I've been climbing here regularly and I love it!Everyone working has actually been really friendly and helpful as are the other climbers who climb here. It can get pretty crowded on weeknights and if there's parties on the weekends but it's never been unbearably crowded for me. Sometimes they run out of shoe sizes when it's busy so if you climb regularly I recommend you get your own shoes!I usually go here to boulder and I'm still pretty new so it will take me a long time to get through all the paths. There are tons of routes for all levels so it keeps it exciting. I know that some routes have had some holds removed to make way for new routes and they have become really awkward because they haven't taken the other holds off and stuff like that so you just have to use your best judgement on what routes are good to take and which ones are just left there just because. I haven't really noticed a super gross smell - it just smells like a rock gym.

All my fiancée and I wanted was some good afternoon fun when we got to Hangar 18. We both know nothing about rock climbing but we do know about customer service and cleanliness. Rude employees alone was enough for me to safely say I'm never going back. Try to be a bit more excited about your jobs fellas, after all you chose it.

My girlfriend and I have had two bad experiences of the four times we have been here... We are originally from Mission Viejo and LOVE that gym. This gym is quick to point out when you are doing something wrong!! The first time we came here we practically begged this curly haired teen in the front to show us how to belay, but he was busy helping four young girls and never came to help us. The second time we came a nice African American kid showed us how to belay. Then the third time we came a douche white guy (maybe a supervisor) embarrassed my girl and I by yelling out that we were doing it wrong. He just passed us on to another guy by telling us to wait for him to teach us! Even though we were taught how to do it already! He tried to play it off as if though he was concerned but had a horrible douche attitude! I am going to try the long beach gym instead of this one even though it is close to my work!! Treat your members better douche!! I am fed up with this gym!!
I love Hangar 18, from the get go I loved the vibes and staff. I love that they give you a monthly free guest pass and offer them shoes and belaying lessons. Favorite rock climbing gym :)
the routes for bordering are way too hard. and why are all the walls for bouldering slanted anyway?

It was a fun experience. The lesson they gave was informative and very helpful since this was our first time. Sensing that we were slow to catch on, our instructor kept one eye on us just to make sure we got the moves down.By the end of the day I was able to climb and hit the top of 3 different set of walls and even braved the free-fall wall.It was a fun experience, but this place does have some kinks in it that may bother some people. 1) The staff seems relatively young and they do not seem to know how to manage the floor. Kids run around  and they leave it to the the parents. Feels like an unkempt playground.2) It also smells like sweat in there.3) Shirtless people showing off their muscles from all the rock climbing.

I'm a relative noob to rock climbing, so take this review with a grain of salt.Hangar 18 is a great alternative to the usual gym experience. The douchey gym rats and meat heads don't exist here. While there are definitely some people here with great physiques, everyone's willing to help you solve a problem with a climb. H-18 has two big bouldering walls, with the perimeter walls set for rope climbs, which double as great traversing climbs. The membership dues are about the same as a typical gym, the staff is really helpful (but you have to ask for it), and there are plenty of challenges for both the noob and the experienced climber. The gym can get kinda busy at times, just like any gym, so if you hate crowds it's best to go during off-peak hours. H-18 doesn't get five stars from me for a couple reasons: 1) Other than a pull-up bar/leg raise machine and a few weights, there isn't any other gym equipment, not even cardio machines. 2) Unlike some other rock gyms, this one doesn't offer classes for yoga/pilates, etc. (though the location in Riverside does offers these classes). 3) last, but not least, they don't have a water fountain! You'd think an establishment designed to make people exert energy, and thus, be thirsty would have a drinking fountain. Nope. Instead they sell cold bottled water for a couple bucks. Nobody's perfect, I guess.Nonetheless, I'm almost certain I'm going to cancel my 24-hour membership and come here instead. Not only will it be cheaper, but also more fun. :)

Went a few weeks back... had lots of fun. Got the starter pkg which included all day pass, gear, and intro class. The instructor was chill... informative... not esp. enthusiastic but we were safe... the class was quick and clear, and we were soon on our way belaying and climbing. The place itself is a little dingy but not bad. The equipment was solid and seemed all in good condition. The staff really chill... at some times ambivalent, but still nice and there when you need them.This was my first time climbing anywhere...but from what i could tell, the few intro climbs I did were ok. There was one climb (when trying to follow the colors) that seemed a bit awkwardly placed... maybe due to my in experience?... but seriously you want me to reach where? when my feet are where?! hehe... Over all I had a great first time experience!

Came here to use an expiring all-inclusive Groupon deal. The lesson was good enough to cover the basics, however none of the call commands were reviewed. I remember these from ice climbing a while back and rock climbing a long time ago..so thought this should be covered especially for newbies.  Luckily for us, we had a friend join us who explained things in more detail which made for a more enjoyable time. Lots of options for climbing, however it was a bit of a surprise to have some guy swing across the rock accidentally getting pretty close to our lesson.  I'm almost wondering if there's not enough space in between people? Or people being more wreckless than I remember?  Most people while I was there took advantage of the bouldering vs. the 2 person rock climbing with rope or the auto belay. Good since more for me for the regular rock climbing. =)   Also...they sell $4 ball of chalk for those who need it...sweaty palms...I definitely could've used it.  Wouldn't mind coming back but best to bring your own equipment.

My rock climbing dreams all started with Ace Ventura. That's right....the Ace man.http://youtu.be/63giSgV9Me0Oh yeah. My dream of learning how to rock climb so I wouldn't drop my side kick raccoon was about to come reality...but it turns out Hangar 18 was not the place to fulfill those dreams.Coming here and meeting my instructor was an absolute buzz kill. I've seen happier Wal-Mart employees.Despite that...he did teach me the basics and drilled into my head that if I did something wrong me or my partner could fall and die. Awesome!I have not been to other rock climbing facilities..but this place seemed kind of....aging to me.It would have been nice if they splurged for padded harnesses cause those REALLY hurt!(esp for the fellas).I did notice a musty smell that some reviews have mentioned...but you get used to it and its not that bad.I do agree with some of the reviews that there is not enough staff members here and they kind of let everyone do their own thing so its a little disorganized.I suggest not coming here for your first time...but if you are already well versed in the rock climbing ways then this place might be good for you.

I bought a Groupon 2 for 1 pass a couple of months ago, and before it expired, I figured it'd be a good experience for my wife to get out and try something different.The gym is well equipped, and the instructor made sure to teach us all the fundamentals of the equipment and technique.  I've tried indoor rock climbing a number of times, so despite being woefully out of shape, I was still able to get up the wall in a respectable amount of time.  I appreciated that they had a variety of walls, even one that was angled at a 50 degree incline for beginners.My wife, who has amazing lower body strength but a surprising lack of upper body strength and a fear of heights was not very enthusiastic at first, but she did a great job on the flatter walls.  We both tried the free climb walls (with protective pads to catch our fall) which were also a nice change of pace.The one thing that I disliked about the gym was the incredibly lackadaisacal attitude the staff had towards the crazy, screaming group of kids celebrating a birthday party.  I couldn't believe how loud and obnoxious some of these kids were:  running around everywhere, wrestling on the mats, shaking ropes and screaming.If I were a personal injury lawyer, I would've been salivating at all the flagrant violations of safety codes the staff was allowing.  Although to be honest, I can't blame the staff completely, as the parents should have started pimp slapping these punk ass kids (I was sorely tempted to do so myself).  Nevertheless, it still took away from the otherwise overwhelmingly positive experience.  Though I should say that not all of the kids were terrors:  one five year old girl was absolutely fearless in scaling the 30 foot wall that a previously rowdy 10 year old boy before her punked out on.  My wife and I stuck around for her descent to give her a round of applause...  I also made sure to make eye contact with the cowardly boy and gave him a scoff that will serve as a slight to his burgeoning manhood for the rest of his formative years.  SCOFF!!!!

LOVE this gym! I'm here often, and it's a great place for me to get my upper-body workout. Unlike some other reviewers, I really don't think this place smells bad at all, but I've probably just gotten used to it. Yes, the place is over-crowded and under-staffed and I was kind of disappointed to see multiple blasts of Groupons go out for this place. I try to go off-hours so I can get some time on the walls. I bring my own gri-gri (yes, I know this isn't an option for everyone) so that makes things easier, too. Just took a great lead class with Andre, who's super helpful and knowledgeable. Looking forward to going back this week...

This is the best rock climbing gym in So Cal. Hangar 18 has everything to offer. There are two boulder caves, auto belay stations, top roping, campus board, and lead climbing. I often climb by myself, so I really appreciate the auto-bely stations. The staff is kick-back, safe, and friendly. The restrooms are well maintained and cleaned regualrly.

Buddy took me rock climbing here with a guest pass. I thought, sure no problem, but man, it's a workout. They have different levels; some of the people here are amazing. Lots of coordination and dexterity involved. Overall, friendly cool folks that are willing to help you out. Could use a little more circulation though and the locker rooms aren't that big.

i didn't go.  i'm writing this review because of my disappointment with the (lack of) customer service at the hawthorne location.  i was considering purchasing the groupon but changed my mind.  here's the wording on the groupon:   "For $30, you get a rock-climbing     package for two (a $60 value)      that includes the following items:      * Two 60-minute belaying lessons      * Two full days of climbing after the lessons      * Rental equipment for two"so i called to ask whether the two days of climbing had to be consecutive to each other.  the guy on the phone said you only get to climb on the same day of your lesson.  i told him the groupon said you get two days of climbing, and he told me that i get to use one "day" and the other person uses the other "day," but it all happens in one day.  i started to ask him a question about bringing my daughter, and he cut me off and told me they were really lessons for adults and not children.  when i told him the kid was 11, meeting the minimum age requirement, he said, "yeah, i guess you could go ahead and bring her.  that's fine."sorry to inconvenience you, rude guy.no wonder you have all these reviews about the not-so-friendly service.  this business's only saving grace must be that rock climbing is a fun activity in itself.

My first time bouldering and balaying. The worker was super nice and helpful. But the place was a bit crowded and there was only one worker. Overall, the activity was fun. A lot of muscle work. Note: DO NOT BUY THE GROUPON - I got the $30 groupon for two classes and later found that the regular student membership is $28 per month unlimited with all the gear and instructions included. Told this difference to the worker and he didnt have a helpful response. Just stayed kind of quiet -_-
