I enjoy doing adventurous & fun things like Rock Climbing so I jumped at the chance to go with my friends.  Good times!  Forgot how hard it was to hang on to the advance level walls.  My arms were shaking!!!The place is not very clean or organized that's why only 3 stars... otherwise great service and good training fun!  Great workout!
Interesting biz. First timer. i need to work on upper body strength. Definitely not a 1st or 3rd date thing. better with familiar friends.

Hanger is a dirtbag's paradise. The number one thing about Hanger is the community. It's the best group of people you will ever meet, and it's inexpensive to boot. There's a reason that a dinky gym is still doing well in Los Angeles when so many gyms are popping up and competing. It's because this gym has fun people, the chillest culture, and the best vibe. If you want to make friends and find a community, go to Hanger. Having moved away, I haven't found anything like it!

my friend had a groupon so i tagged along...i would think the rating would be higher if not for that reason...find out why below:preparation//don't go when people have groupons! everyone tries to maximize and the place ends up being overcrowded =/FYI, if you're renting, you will need to leave car keys as a deposit for the gearlessons//***half our group were seasoned wall monkeys....i mean athletes and the other half were n00bs that needed lessonsthe lessons themselves were easy and great, if only there weren't SO MANY PEOPLE that day...the instructor kept running off to give multiple lessons...so what would normally take 20-25 mins ended up taking almost 1 hour to learnfacilities//****the walls are color-coded and easy to understand...there is a wide range in difficulty so there should be fun for alli also like the set up in the middle where the tired people can just hang out up top and watch their friends continue climbing below all around the room~*~it's a fun experience and very easy for the first-timer!

Just my favorite place ever! I try to get here a couple of times a week to stay in solid outdoor form. Watch out Bear Grylls I have got your number!Hangar 18 has tons of top rope climbs and lead climbs for all skill levels rated from 5.3 to 5.14 and bouldering from VB to V14. They also offer belay training, shoe and harness rentals. Make sure to ask for Andre when you get there. He is always happy to assist and will make you want to come back time and time again.Hope you check it out and maybe I'll see you there.

$16 for an entire day. $2 for the harness to strap into. Love that thing which makes me feel safe while climbing these high walls. Good activity on a day when you have nothing else to do! I make that statement since I'm not a huge fan of rock climbing but I'd go with a friend, every so often.

I was reasonably impressed with the facility. Lots of climbs with the skill levels clearly marked. The staff is pretty well trained and the equipment is very well maintained. I'm glad they use the Grigri as the only belay device here. It almost idiot proofs the experience for new climbers. It's worth checking out. Bring your own beverages... unless you like the taste of gatorade.

I got myself and my friend E. a pass through groupon - 2 one month memberships for the price of one. I've done plenty of real-life bouldering, but I've never learned to belay and all that, so I figured I should try.The first few times we went we just went bouldering, which is of course really fun. I understand that for more experienced rock-climbers this is not the most challenging gym - but it's a great place to go work out, get some practice in, go with a friend or significant other, etc. Our belay lesson was taught by an exceptionally laconic fellow who warmed up to us after about 30 minutes (before that we got the sense we were bothering him). However, it was a very busy night at the gym, so I can totally understand. Other than that, everyone has been very friendly, and there are some times when it is completely uncrowded (early mornings, mid-day in the week). I recommend it as a decent gym, with friendly folk - the equipment is in good shape, though the floors are a bit in need of repair (but not so much that you feel in danger).

Took a belay course and bought a day pass, along with rentals for shoes, harness and belay device at the Long Beach location.  This place was clean, but there was only one person working and it took awhile for us to get any desk service.  When we did, he gave us a quick lesson and we were on our own for the rest of the day, which was fine.No chalk provided, so bring your own.  The routes are pretty good, but they don't go up very high -- maybe 30ft?  There's a wide range of difficulties from 5.5 to 5.13.  I stuck to the 5.7-5.9 range and had a good time.  There's a nice wall with some mock-natural holds too.All in all, satisfied -- I will likely get a membership to this gym as there are 4 locations and the Long Beach one is closest to my school.  Enjoy!
Great place. I went there with my gf for the 1st time. The staff was very friendly and helpful. I like the layout and variety of the walls. Over all great experience.

This is definitely the best rock gym in the South Bay.  A membership isn't terribly expensive (about $30 a month, depending).  If top roping is your thing, you will run out of climbs in a couple of hours.  However considering how short the wall is, they come up with some interesting climbs.  They have a fantastic slab and I wish they set some routes with balance problems instead of designating it the kiddie wall.  In recent months they've done a better job at resetting the routes more frequently.  This gym is best for bouldering.  There are a lot of very, very challenges problems.  However if you are not endowed with fantastic upper body strength you will find it very difficult to climb above a V0.Andre is one cool guy; be sure to chat him up if you come here.  I also happen to like Danny as he is always willing to give hints on bouldering problems.Children can be a problem here.  If they happen to be well-behaved, it's not an issue.  But when it is a particularly rambunctious group, it can be downright dangerous.  I was bouldering once and a kid flopped down on the crash pad beneath me.  If I wasn't keeping an eye out, I definitely could have fallen on top of  him.

my buddy linda n. had a groupon to this place and invited me to try it out with her. having never tried rock climbing this was an eye opening experience.we seemed to have arrived at the right time. we were helped out right away by one of the staff members who proceeded to educate us on the basics of climbing which are quite intricate. but despite the intricacies of rope handling and safety linda and i felt comfortable enough to try it out and try it out we did!the staff member was right there with us for most of the time until we got the hang of it. however, one tip for beginners: you're probably not going to last very long as your hands and arms start feeling like jelly and your body becomes exhausted after a few tries. not to mention there is only so much climbing you can do over a wall. so it does become a little monotone and you realize this is more like a gym than a recreational activity-it helps build up your skills and body but the real adventure is out there in the mountains.with that being said however, i found the experience quite educational. being around that whole climber scene was interesting. seeing all these folks own the walls like monkeys up on trees was something else. the place is well run and organized and the gear seemed to be in condition. wish i had more time to be into this kind of stuff but alas i love the outdoors too much to be cooped up in a large warehouse for long hours.

Bought the Groupon a while ago (as so many did) but last Sunday was the first day Ted and I had both had off in a long time. What better way to enjoy it than to rock climb the crap out of ourselves? I was a little nervous at first but Ted was super encouraging. The staff there was busy, but helpful, and we didn't feel like they left us hanging. I started on the beginners wall and it went swimmingly. Ted and I eventually worked our way to the expert wall. I made it all of a foot off of the ground but Ted was able to almost reach the top. There is a decent amount of variability here so I can see spending a few hours trying to master the walls. Ted and I are contemplating a membership. It was a great workout and we also got to spend time together. I would recommend that they use our membership money to fix the floors. It's pretty questionable. Still, a great time and we will for sure be back.

Bought a really great lesson deal on Groupon and had a total blast. My best friend came to town this weekend (YAY) and what better way to show her Los Angeles than to take her rock climbing ?! Exactly. Because that's what Los Angelenos do best. Drove out to Hanger 18 (still marked as Beach City Rocks on the plaza sign) and was a little skeptical at first. It seems like a lot of large warehouses and storage facilities and it is difficult to tell where the gym is, but just turn right into the plaza and drive to the straight back. Now, I have no basis for comparison, but I think our lesson went fairly well. It was a little intimidating at first, there are all these really fit half naked dudes doing free climbs and running up walls. Yes, I said half naked. That might be your incentive right there. But, Andre was very good about being friendly the entire time, teaching us the four point check, and making sure we were pretty well versed in the process. He had us attempt belay climbing which is SUPER fun because you get to have your friend's life in your hands....and then yours in theirs. Luckily, I trust Grace (my bff) with everything in the world. Andre (who speaks fluent French and is very interesting to talk to while you're taking slack away from your friend) taught us how to climb the wall, take slack, and lower the climber. We tried a couple different walls before my friend said it was time to go to the beach (she's from Austin, Texas...low beach accessibility there). The climb is a total rush. I can see why people get into this -- although you are relying on someone else as your sort of buffer, the climb is really all up to you and your endurance. Once you get past the heights thing (which is only somewhat scary) the ability to push yourself up and trust in your abilities is where the real adrenaline comes from. Grace often had to tell me to slow down because I was moving too fast for a little bit there. I just got super excited! I have no idea if I would be capable of doing this either long term or outdoors (where there aren't any pretty rock colors to tell you where you to go!), but I think I would definitely try this again. The price is right even if you don't have a groupon, and it's totally worth the experience.
Pro:Knowledgeable staffCubbies and lockersGender separate locker rooms w/ showersGood range of difficultiesDecent equipmentOpen lateCon:Smells like feet!!Crowded (many kids)Use carkeys as collateral
Great place, I come here all the time but they keep playing the same ten 80s songs on loop every time I come here. Really weird.

I bought their groupon for a month trial and we went in last night to give it a try. I was pleasantly surprised! I have a slight fear of heights but after climbing the intro wall with a ton of huge grips and reaching the top, I gained the confidence to climb the harder walls. They give you a great class to teach you everything that you know to tie the knots and belay your partner. It's a great all around workout as well and I will definitely be going back and incorporating it in my workout.

My brother and I climbed here yesterday and it was a pretty solid climbing gym. There are not as many top-roped routes as I would like but since we don't live here and would only climb here when visiting our parents, I'm sure we won't ever be bored on our biannual sojourns. The routes seemed a bit skewed towards routes favoring those with superior upper body strength; there were far more big hand holds/handles than good foot/toe holds on most routes, even going up to 5.10+. Most climbs we saw were 5.8-5.11, but I heard one member of staff ask another to put up some 5.5's for the kids there so I'm sure the staff would be happy to accommodate your level if the walls on any particular day were lacking variety in grade.The people who work here are incredibly nice and when we were there, several groups of kids were climbing and all were well behaved and supervised so I'd recommend this to anyone wishing to unload their brood for a morning or afternoon of agility and confidence building. I had to rent gear and could smell the shoes a mile away so definitely bring socks if you are renting and to anyone working there, you might want to invest in the spray they use at the bowling alley. There is one shower in the women's locker room, not sure about the men's, and it's BYO towel and toiletries.

I was here when visiting LA recently and I agree with many reviewers when they say the place is dirty. It is truly a filthy gym, and there is no need for that. The ones I go to in Toronto are not exactly uppercrust like Sender One, but they are at least clean! This place is also very small, and the top rope wall are rather low, with limited routes, and painted over holds so they are somewhat slippery. We were told that it is a gym without a lot of money, hence no grigris at every station and hence the crappy old painted holds for the top rope stations.. but how does a "poor" gym have so many locations? Poor gym or stingy owner(s)? I also find the grading slightly easier than the gyms I am used to (e.g. 5.9 feels like 5.8, 5.10c feels like 5.10a or b). Aside from the filth, the bouldering is probably the best feature here.. except for the small, thin, filthy crash pads that you have to move around as needed (kinda like outside.. and unlike my usual gyms where they have very thick, unmovable padding underneath the entire bouldering areas), and the fact that you cannot always see the colour of the holds because they are so covered in chalk and never seem to get cleaned.
I went here last week, my mom had bought my some tickets for xmas. $30 for all day pass, an instructor teaches you the correct ways climbing and using the harness. Pretty cool, good work out

As good as it gets.  September 17  Birthday party for grown ups.  The 9 of us-not a one with climbing experience-had such a fantastic time.  Nathan and Julia were smart, helpful, funny, and full of help. By the end of the day, the most trepidation in our clan were going vertical.  It was awesome.  Thanks,Kevin Tiernan

Went here for free because my friend had a guest pass!  The instructor was very helpful.  I had never done rock climbing before so it was scary.  I have yet to try all of the walls, considering this was my first time and we came one hour before it closed.  Will go back in the future.
A lot of fun, not too expensive, funny workers, challenging...but you do have to wait quite a bit for gear if you go on a weekend especially a cold, grey, wet one.

I went on a free night last week.  I fell in love with rock climbing and Hangar 18, which I hear is the best rock climbing gym in LA.  I don't have much experience with others, but the staff was very friendly and the walls had a good range of challenges.I can't wait to go back again and I'm giving serious thought to buying a membership!

Bouncy mats on the floor, general instruction, tether yourself up and get to climbing. I had never rock climbed and found it challenging and fun- albeit more then scary when I had to let go and free fall once I reached the top. I ass planted more then a couple of times and have since decided that any excursion involving real rocks in the real outdoors would be a big no no for me. I like the ass bone too much. On the general instruction note: There was very little actual instruction given by the people who worked there (aside from showing you how to safely harness yourself 'in'). Thankfully there was a father and daughter team climbing next to us and he gave us step by step instruction on 'how to' come down from the top properly, which were beginner knobs and which were advanced, etc... Good to go with someone who knows what the heck they're doing so you can get schooled properly. Overall a fun experience, I would consider going back. Pearls of wisdom to the newbie: MAKE SURE to bring a pair of socks and a bottle of Lysol. Everyone shares shoes and they're F.u.N.k.Y.

This place was pretty fun. Lots of space to climb whether you are a beginner (like me) or advance. I came with a friend to try it out since I've been looking to get into rock climbing. Even with an appointment time we had to wait for about 30 minutes until they started showing us what to do as a beginner. Also they were low on rental carabiners. Not such a great thing if you offer a beginner's class at the same time. Granted it was a Saturday morning which I'd imagine is one of their busiest times. All in all I think it is a great place to go if you are more than a beginner with your own gear. I definitely think it is worth a visit if you're into the activity.

Initially I checked out the pics on the website and the facility looked nice, which it is. We came to the gym to do the adult intro pkg. Upon arriving we were greeted by a smug cashier/ front desk person. After filling out the liability waiver, we were waiting to have everything else done. The smug cashier's friend/ girlfriend came by and brought the guy lunch, all his attention was focused on her. Needless to say, it was annoying and certainly lacking customer service. We didn't let it bother us. The trainer who gave us the mini lesson was lacking any personality and enthusiasm. It was the equivalent to a self service kiosk. I think I'd prefer that instead! At least my expectations would have been met. He also seemed somewhat lackadaisical of safety precautions, which to me should never be taken lightly. His instructions and lessons were fine, however, we certainly felt like a number though.After we finished, we returned everything and as I was waiting to pay, the cashier said thanks and bye. Well, for those who are looking to get a free package, you should go when the guy works the front. I think his name started with a D. My conscience wouldn't let me walk out of there without paying for a service which was rendered. The clerk who took Mr. D's place informed us we should have been asked to pay in the beginning. But somebody was thinking with the wrong head...All in all, nice facility, but poor customer service/ relations. For me, I'd gladly pay more for better service.
I've been going to Hangar 18 now for almost a year and love bouldering and climbing here. The music's always really good too!

A great gym. The regulars are really nice and easy to talk to, which helps when you're just starting out. The staff is nice. It's a little dusty in there and it can get a little stuffy when the gym is packed, but it's usually not a big problem.

Fuckn' A.  Hangar 18 in LA!  I use to climb at the original Hangar in Upland...that was and still is a great gym to climb at.  Firstly, it's inexpensive!  It's $15 bucks cheaper than the gym I am at right now.  They have auto belay devices, though some are in for servicing right now, I love the ideal that you can go climb on the wall by yourself!  It did take some getting use to though; falling back and trusting that the belay device brings you down slowly.

This is an awesome rock gym, but they are over-crowded and under-staffed. The day I went, there were only two employees overseeing the 40 (or so) patrons. And to make matters worse (not to mention unsafe), both employees were giving lessons while simultaneously keeping an eye on the front door and cash register/counter.Plus, they ran out of equipment and there was a waiting list for grigri's (which they didn't even bother to tell people until after they paid). I never made it to the top of the waiting list; and the staff were rude about it to boot. One staff member asked my name and then made jokes about how long I'd have to wait and then proceeded to complain to me how long he'd been waiting to go on his lunch break.I was really disappointed and frustrated with my experience there. I really want to go back because it's a really cool gym, but they seriously need to do something about the staff and the availability of equipment (or at the very least, warn people before they pay that there's a wait list). My recommendation: save yourself the headache and go somewhere else.

Direct quote from one of the staff (11:30am on a Saturday)."I can't believe I woke up before noon for this..."That pretty much sums up the place.  Pretty nice experience spoiled by a staff that generally could not care less.

I was very unsatisfied! I am a regular climber and i decided to visit the gym with some friends.. wish i hadn't. two out of my four friends were injured when falling off of bouldering wall. one of them BROKE his ankle and the other sprained a ligament in the right side bone of his leg. both injuries were due to the fact that the padding system is terrible! there are mmany spaces in between pads on of which is three feet down! and to add to that there was a mouse running around in the pads and one of my friends was insulted by an employee! overall, not a good experience! Ps: floors and pads are filthy and setting isn't that great...

Excellent during the day, but a bit crowded late afternoon/evening. Plenty of variety in difficulty. As an experienced climber I like the atmosphere, but may not be as helpful for anyone new to the sport.

I too got one of those online deals for the wife and I for a month of rock climbing. This was our first adventure for rock climbing and we got everything down from the semi-friendly staff who taught us the basics from putting on the harness making a figure 8 knot and using the belay so that we wouldn't kill each other.For that last three weeks  i've gotten in 4 visits to the gym. The garage doors are typically open allowing lots of natural air constantly flowing keeping the stank down. The place itself i think is pretty small or there are at times too many people. As far as a workout it really tires me out really fast which i figure is a good thing, but makes me feel really weak at the same time.

I had to reschedule a bachelor party last minute and the staff were extremely helpful and useful and even helped my party by giving us all a discount out of sympathy for our hectic situation! They really made my brother's bachelor party (at least during the day haha). Great place! Great service! Hours of fun!

First time ever doing any climbing. I was a little intimidated at first but after a few minutes of watching people, I gave it a try. I felt comfortable here.  Only two issues: little kids running around because of bday parties, which is dangerous in this environment... and ventilation could have been a bit better inside.

I went here with my nose ready to sniff the stench of feet as others have mentioned, but I didn't catch that in the air that day. Lucky us. We rocked this place out for beginners who shunned lessons! I wish I could remember the blond guy's name who so patiently gave us a quickie tutorial and sweet encouragement before we hoisted ourselves up on the automatic belay. Yes, there were some splattering 'falls' off the wall. Yes, young children scurried up the wall before we even had our harnesses hooked up. And yes. Our limbs were burning and sore the second we sat down in the car to leave. Despite that, we had an awesome time. For about $20, we got a good workout, talked to nice people and found a new activity to do in the South Bay. I'd recommend it for anyone who, like us, just wants to try something new. Take lessons if you want, but honestly, it's kind of fun to wing it.

This is a rating for someone interested in a kid's birthday party. I visited them today to get info and was really put off by Andre's attitude.  They are used to selling a pre-determined package - 2 hours and that's it.  If you need more than 10 minutes to set up, forget it.  If you want a longer party, he has no idea, "I guess just double the cost given for a 2 hour party."  It's clear that parties are just a sideline they aren't very excited about.  The party space is a narrow area with a table, a picnic table and a couple of chairs thrown around and a filthy carpet.  They're worried about a face painter making a mess on that stained carpet.  You access the space via a tight winding staircase.  Sorry grandma, you'll have to sit in the car.  Other than climbing there's nothing else for kids to do and they're not allowed to climb the other boulders so they just have to stand around waiting for their turn.

I went back to this gym recently (bad life choice) and I have to say it is even worst! customer service horrible, the place is dirty, and the ropes need to be changed out for safety reasons. If  I were you go to the other hanger 18 gyms they are way better! there is now one in Long beach.

If you're interested in trying out Rock Climbing, Hanger 18 is a great place to start. They've got a huge area of indoor rock walls, split into free-climbing (bouldering?), lead climbing, and belay climbing. I should start out by saying the only climbing experience I had before heading over to Hanger 18 was a county fair rock-wall. Not the strongest preparation for a full climbing lesson and day of climbing! But we got a great deal - $30 for 2 adult lessons, equipment, and a day pass - so we headed over early on Saturday morning for an adventure. They started out by giving us our equipment and teaching us how to tie the correct figure-8 knot between our harnesses and the lead ropes. They were very focused on safety, so we had to practice the steps several times before we could move on to the next one. After the knots lesson, we moved over to the wall and learned steps 3 and 4 -- how to connect the second person to the ropes and make sure they were tied in (after all, if you're climbing and start to fall, your partner on the ground should be sure your ropes are tight enough so you don't hit the ground!) During all of this, our instructor was carefully watching us and answering my multiple questions. He was incredibly patient and very informative. I was the first to climb, starting out on one of the ~5.5 ranked climbs (all of the belay climbs are on a range). The instructor stayed with us for our first few climbs, telling me where to look for the next hand or footholds if I ever got stuck. After he felt we were safe enough, we were given free reign of the gym. I'm so glad that we tried this place out -- I had a blast and, despite being quite sore today from using shoulder muscles I haven't in quite a while, I can't wait to go back! From what I saw, there are monthly memberships as well as weekend trips to different outdoor climbing areas. I would definitely recommend Hanger 18 if you're looking for a climbing gym or want to try a fun new workout.

I got a groupon for a month pass to go here. I just moved to LA and was stoked to find some good rock climbing gyms, but this place was such a disappointment! The walls were super short for roped climbing, although I didn't really care because I mainly wanted to boulder. So what REALLY irked me was how disorganized the bouldering routes were! All of the gyms that I've gone to mark their bouldering routes very clearly with colored tape. But this place marks their routes according to the color handhold, which is a really flawed system. The holds are all dirty so color varies. An orange hold, depending on how worn or dirty it is, could be mistaken for a pink or red hold. So while you're bouldering on a route you'll look to find the next hold and have to debate whether that hold over there is orange or pink... then you get lost and frustrated. They also didn't seem to plan out their routes very well and the holds were placed really awkwardly. And there was no indication of where the routes ended. And the biggest flaw of all: they are really restricted with the routes they set because they can only set them using the same color holds. That is SO DUMB! If they just used colored tape to mark routes then they could open up a whole new range of possibilities as far as creating original, fun routes. This place blows, I wish I could get a refund. Anyhoo, I'm going to start climbing at Rockreation instead.

I am an avid boulderer, climbing shorter but often harder routes with no ropes. I have been to many climbing gyms and at one point I had a membership at both Rockreation and Hangar 18 at the same time. Since Rockreation is the only other gym nearby and I have climbed extensively at both gyms I will be comparing the two.If you are into to bouldering I would recommend Hangar 18 over rockreation. Both have fun interesting routes but Hangar 18's bouldering area is much bigger. Also unlike Rockreation H18 offers boulders that can be topped out. For sport and lead climbing I think Rockreation has a small advantage.H18 also has a systems training wall and Rockreation does not.But Rockreation does have gym equipments(stationary bike and weights) and H18 doesn't have any gym equipments besides a pull up and dip station.H18 also seems to be cheaper than Rockreation. Also unlike Rockreation, H18 does not require a start-up fee or have a cancellation fee for their membership.(Accurate to the best of my knowledge at the time of the review)The staff at H18 is also friendly and helpful.Just remember to bring a water bottle! Unlike Rockreation they do not have a drinking fountain but they do sell water and drinks at the front desk.Both gyms are good in their own way but I personally prefer H18.***I saw one reviewer complaining about the floor condition. In my most recent visit they seemed to be addressing the problem by changing out the flooring.

This place was pretty good. My boyfriend brought me here. He was pretty into rock climbing and wanted to get me into it as well. This was my first time joining a gym, so I was pretty excited. My boyfriend said this place wasn't that great, but I really enjoyed it. They had a bunch of bouldering options, and then around the sides there was belaying options too. I wish there were more auto-belays, because my boyfriend enjoyed bouldering more. It would have been nice to do the auto-belay, but there was only one (maybe two?) auto-belays for beginners. I think there were two, but every time I looked, the second one was closed off for some reason. But the people were nice and signing up and the belay lessons were really easy. It's small, which is something I like. I didn't want anything too daunting for my first climbing gym. If you're just starting out, I recommend this place. But apparently if you've been climbing for a while, you may want to look else-where. Like I said, I liked it. I saw plenty of families taking their kids there, which was cute. Although, don't go Monday nights. There's some sort of kids climbing club and it's a pain because the kids just run up and take routes your about to start and they are just crazy running everywhere. It's a pain. Avoid Monday nights if you can!

Only came here for bouldering, and it's got lots of it.  However, it's a tight place, so I cannot imagine when it gets busy.  Was great in the morning during the week when there weren't a lot of people.  Easy parking and $16 for the day.

My friend is a big time spider monkey climbing fanatic, so when invited to try climbing out as his free guest I threw my phobia of heights to the wind and as the commercialized goddess of war says, decided to "just do it." Climbing is super fun and a great work-out, but alas, I have to remind myself that I write this review not on the sport, but the business. So comments on the oh-so important lesson for the newb. The guy teaching the lesson 1) seemed like he'd much rather be somewhere else and 2) so non-chalantly threw in "pointers" on how not to seriously injure or kill myself...I would have missed some had I not seen the wide eyed alarm on my fellow classmates' faces. Can you say YOIKS!? 3) The second time I went, felt like I got duped because I'm still new. I paid to rent a harness, but there were no gri-gri, and being 4th on the wait list was told I probably wouldn't get one at all. Thanks buddy for telling me this after I paid for the rental! Look past the less than enthusiastic staff, this is a decent gym to start off to learn.
I joined this gym a few months back and really enjoyed it.  Andre was a great help other climbers for the most part were friendly.  Month to month so if your looking for a test ride here it is.

I've been going here for about a year and a half now. Its a decent gym with its positives and negatives. I go here because its the closest place and they have a decent membership price if you're a college student. I'm reviewing this from a rock climber's perspective.First, I want to correct a mistake others have mentioned. The routes here are not determined by the color of the holds; they are determined by hold color AND tape color. Its a good idea but poorly executed. The problem is that when they set their routes, they spray paint some of their holds to make sure they are matching colors. This makes some of the holds more slick. Also, the paint on the smaller foot holds will chip and the underlying color will show. A lot of times you don't even know which foot holds to use because of this. Also, because the wall is made of rock and not wood like other gyms, the tape easily comes off. Anyone that climbs here a lot knows tape ALWAYS comes off. Sometimes its not a big deal and you can figure out the route based on hold color, but sometimes they will have 2 separate routes of the same hold color cross each other. When the tape comes off, you don't really know which route that particular hold belongs to.The staff is hit or miss. Some of them seem pretty helpful and nice. Others seem like they are only there because they have to be.Like I said, the wall is made of some kind of fake rock. This is SOOO much better than having wood because the rock has features you can use for your feet. The routes are pretty good, but compared to Rock City which has GREAT routes, most of the climbs seem pretty bland. There are A LOT of climbs with really big moves that seemed like they were made for 6' 2" climbers. I think most regulars here will agree that the climbs can be really reachy. It can be a bad thing, but then again you start to get really strong.This is a good gym if you're already a decent climber, but could be a bad experience if you're going for the 1st time.

+ the cool spiky-haired woman at the front desk was incredibly helpful. we're fairly new to climbing and it was our first time here, and i liked how she stood around to check each of us on our knots/belaying before going on her merry way, answered all our stupid beginner questions, etc. the gym is big and airy, with enough routes in the 5.7-5.9 category and bouldering to keep me occupied and challenged. they also had a bunch of much harder-looking things, none of which i'm going to be tackling any time soon!came on a sunday afternoon, and there were maybe 15 other people there -- not crowded at all. -- pricewise, $16/day pass is ok but i wouldn't mind it being a couple bucks cheaper!

Was there with a group all ages mostly beginners. Adrian was sooooooooo helpful and nice.  He gave us an introductory lesson and made sure we had all the safety information clear. Once we got the hang of it, we had a great time. It's a great workout. They offer monthly membership as well as one off use of their facility.
I love this place. I randomly wanted to rock climb and looked for gyms. I wish it was closer to home, though. Stoney point park is fun although not as noobie friendly as the gym.

Been climbing at this gym for over two years now.  It is definitely one of the better climbing gyms in socal.  It is a bit small, but the price is also less in comparison to others.  The staff is super chill, and the climbers that frequent the gym are all friendly and helpful.  There's an assortment of top-rope, bouldering, and lead routes for all levels, including a very fun lead cave.

I LOVE THIS PLACE.. my bf and i were about to go to the one in riverside but since we were in upland already we dropped my to see how it was like... my bf already rock climbs but never at this gym.. it was cool... they helped me with everything. they explaned everything very well and even help hook some lines up to i can climb different parts of the wall... it wsa cool.. the only thing that i have to say is that there should b more room.. this place is tiny compared to the one in riverside.... but over all i had fun... i would do it again anytime! i still get a kick out of the name "GREE-GREE" HAHAH.... LOVE IT!!!

Was at the gym early this morning.  Checked the website before I went and noted a $9 day pass before noon special.  The guy at the front desk did not even acknowledge that the gym was running a special when I asked for a day pass.  Then once I mentioned the special, gave me the correct price of course, but excused himself for poor customer service/climbing etiquette by saying it was gym policy not to offer the "internet" special unless the customer mentioned it.  I def got a b.s. corporate vibe, not very friendly climber like, and quite frankly disappointing.  I am from CO and not new to the gym scene and was surprised by his behavior.  I wasn't able to climb/boulder anything super hard due to not climbing in months, but the v5 and under stuff that I did hit was alright.  Nothing that was crazy original or got me psyched to be at the gym.  I am 5'1 so the setting was typical, big and consistent with lock offs, like I said nothing new or original.  They do have a lot of newer holds, which is nice.  The route setting was super weird, no taped routes but color coordinated holds throughout the route.  Overall, this will not be my go to gym, I am closer to the 210 and the arc, so I will check that out next.
